column10: Amazing storyline
yes

Its good if you don't like being punished in management/assembly games.

Boils down to cutting shapes, rotating them, painting them, and then assembling them.

Levels increase in difficulty until its just annoying more than fun.

You play the entire game on one board so you can reuse factories but if youre anything like me you delete everything to start over and make something more efficient/convenient based on location

At first its very addictive and fun as you try to figure things out, then once you understand everything you realize its a very boring and very repetitive game.

Perhaps the most annoying feature is that copy/pasting designs (essential in a factory/assembly game) cost in game currency which is more frustrating than anything. Should be free, no argument.

Found myself alt tabbing/idleing just to get factories to finish the level instead of building massive ones that could do it quickly, no incentive to do otherwise really.

Really no risk to playing the game, you are a godlike camera that can go anywhere and do anything. Nothing costs anything (aside from the one feature which should be free ie. copy/paste)

Overall: If you enjoy a casual assembly/factory style game I guess this is for you but I really wouldnt recommend it to anyone. I got bored quick and found myself playing it just to see if it got more interesting. If you want this game but better and with a real challenge I would highly recommend Factorio. Theres a bit of a learning curve but its this game but better in every way in my opinion.
I stopped playing this game to save myself from a full blown addiction to it, but man I think about playing this again all the time.

This game is the dog's bollocks. Learning efficiency in the beginning is so rewarding, but I dare say, the  "make everything machine" (MAM) using the wire output from the hub is the ultimate goal of this game. (some exceptions). The MAM is so difficult to build and program, I had to keep my notebook near me at all times for 2-3 weeks. Inspiration will strike you in the middle of the night, in the middle of your work shifts, while driving your car. I urge you, do not cheat and copy someone else's design. Come up with it on your own ...because it is one of the most difficult and rewarding experiences you will have in gaming. Once I got mine working, I ran the game all day while I'm at work, while I'm asleep. I built a "shape recorder" into my design that shows you what its been building. Amazing what this thing can do. 7 days ago I was at level 28, now I'm on level 93. God speed with your designs

I'm a fan of Zachtronics automation puzzlers, and Satisfactory.  I picked up Shapez on sale to try.  Initially I thought it seemed a bit simple but I'd just continue for a bit... and then suddenly several hours had passed.  It's a nice little factory game with a few nice touches.  I appreciated that copy/paste is unlocked later, and also that you have to make tokens to use it with.  I liked the end objective of the "Make Anything Machine" that completely automates the factory; I managed this after about 30 hours, and then ran it forward for a while to reach level 100.

If I had any gripes it's that some of the stacked shapes are a bit hard to comprehend properly.  I also didn't quite understand the level vs upgrades thing properly at the beginning, so I played for a while before realising I should have been upgrading my tech more.  After initially pointing it out early, if you don't happen to have accidentally made an upgrade available, you can completely ignore upgrades after that point unless you click on the icon.

Recommended for anyone who likes factory builders but is wary of trying Factorio in case they lose their entire life to it.

a lot of automation games really explode beyond my ability to track them; shapez keeps my focus on tight production lines rather than tech trees and resource costs. it removes the cruft and gets to the heart of what is my favorite stuff about automation games.

The game is going to keep throwing new shape and color and rotation combinations to unlock faster belts, higher quality of life stuff, etc. The folks who love creating perfect blueprints will love this game, because once you reach the ability to use them, you can refine to your heart's content. Pros:
- Can't not compare it to Factorio - it is a fun production line game.
- Good sense of progression.
- It is challenging enough but also quite chilled out.
- I am 9 hrs in and looking forward to playing more of it.

Cons:
- The game really, really needs a system that saves blueprints, rather than copy/paste only one blueprint at any one time.  I find it baffling how blueprints are the weakest part of the game, when games like this rely so heavily on this feature.
- Blueprints should also be free - the game claims "this game is not an idle game", but it is and idle game if you're waiting for blueprint parts to fill.
- Some resources are way too close together and you are sometimes forced to just build on top of other resources to maintain a decent layout.

[h1] Shapez - A Masterpiece of Efficiency and Creativity[/h1]
Shapez is an addictive gem that effortlessly marries the elements of efficiency and creativity, offering players a uniquely engaging experience that keeps you hooked from start to finish. With a supportive and vibrant community, enriched by a plethora of excellent mods, Shapez stands as a testament to the power of innovation in the gaming world.

The core of Shapez lies in its ability to captivate players with its ingenious puzzle-solving mechanics. As you delve deeper into the game, you'll find yourself constantly striving to make your designs more efficient and clever. The sense of satisfaction that accompanies each optimization is incredibly rewarding and serves as a testament to the game's brilliant design.

One of Shapez's standout features is the dedicated and passionate community that has grown around it. The availability of excellent mods further extends the game's lifespan, introducing fresh challenges and opportunities for creativity. The support and engagement from fellow players and modders enhance the overall experience and make Shapez a vibrant and dynamic gaming ecosystem.

The game's intuitive interface and elegant design make it accessible to both newcomers and veterans of the genre. It strikes a perfect balance between complexity and accessibility, ensuring that players can immerse themselves in its world without feeling overwhelmed. This accessibility is a testament to the developers' commitment to creating an enjoyable gaming experience for everyone.

In conclusion, Shapez is a masterpiece that blends efficiency and creativity into an addictive gaming experience. It challenges players to constantly improve their designs while fostering a sense of community and collaboration through its excellent mods. If you're looking for a game that will keep you engaged for hours on end and encourage your problem-solving skills, Shapez is the perfect choice. Dive into this world of shapes and efficiency, and you won't be disappointed.

I like factory games, I like automation games, I like puzzle games.

This is primarily a puzzle game, with a copy-paste factory mechanic. I can see how people would like this, especially if you've never played anything else in the genre. Perhaps it's a good entry point, but I think not. It misses enough of the key ideas of the genre, and has enough little papercuts, graphics glitches, and QOL issues, that I fear it might turn someone off the genre entirely.

Do yourself a favor, go buy Factorio instead.

The only difficult part of the game is figuring out the obtuse way required to combine a shape. The actual automation portions of it can be solved by simply creating yourself a few template types and copy-pasting the perfect necessary factory. Once you've built the perfect chainable combiner factory, painter factory, paint mixer, each level becomes "figure out what's needed to combine the shape" and then just copy-pasting.
Not knowing what shapes are going to be needed in the future levels is frustrating because you don't know what you should tear down and what you should keep.

It's not a BAD game. I enjoyed most of the 22 hours I spent in it. But I don't feel like there's a lot left to do or look forward to that actually interests me, so it's hard to say I'd recommend it.

I really enjoyed shapez -- until I didn't! Once I needed the windmill shapes, it became too tedious to be fun. I got more than 10 hours of gametime out of it. That's a decent amount for me and I'm really happy with that. I uninstalled it immediately upon learning that windmills don't appear naturally: I just lost the will to play.

It was EXTREMELY fun while I was hooked. The music goes quite well and the experience of building out the factory was extremely satisfying. The map is MASSIVE and it's a lot of fun to build such a large and complex machine. For the first 14 levels, the difficulty and upgrades ramp up sensibly. BONUS: the game is open source and playable on the Web if you want to test it out before picking it up on Steam.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

- Very fun and addicting
- Infinite map
- 10 different machines, each with different variants (You can get more with mods!)
- Wide variety of shapes you can produce
- Colorblind mode
- Many supported languages (yes, this includes English)
- Relaxing soundtrack
- You can build machines without using any shapes/resources, meaning you don't have to grind for 10 hours to build a factory
- Mobile support

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- For some features, such as mods, you will have to go to a website outside of Steam (I will link all the Shapez websites [b]THAT I KNOW OF[/b] below)
- No workshop support
- Requires brainpower
- May occasionally glitch and delete part of your factory
- May freeze for a few seconds if you select another window and then go back to the game

[h1]Overall score:[/h1]

9/10

[h1]Links:[/h1]

Shape generator: https://viewer.shapez.io/

This is like if you took Factorio and removed all of the charm and survival challenge from it. A soulless puzzle-esque logistics game that misses the point of logistics in reality; moving real things from A to B in increasingly complex measures and dealing with the complexities of nature, people, time, seasons, etc. Most logistics games include some of these elements but this game does not, aside from procedurally generated deposits.

I am not a fan of minimalism so if you are this review can be safely ignored but if you find the idea of staring at a light/dark screen with almost no variation in colour all day to be an unpleasant idea do not buy this game. 

Furthermore the challenge itself is weak, it's not a difficult game, but in spite of that they feel the need to lock blueprints behind the 12th level which just increases _tedium_ and not challenge.

shapez is an excellent minimalistic factory game that truly takes the science of mass production to a visually artistic level. While shapes seem simple to create at first, they get much more complex with painting and stacking, and it is incredibly fun to figure out each new logistical challenge. You also have infinite buildings, resource patches, and land, making this an even more chill and minimalist game. (Copy and pasting works differently, at a slight cost though.) 

Of course, comparing any factory game to Factorio is inevitable, so some QoL features that would be nice to have are smart belt dragging (auto place tunnels), side belt loading, flipping blueprints, and a blueprints tab. However, the belt planner and map markers are great tools for building and managing production. Look at all the pretty shapez.
Its just a really fun and addicting game

But Factorio runs buttery smooth on it. As do other more graphically intensive games, Diablo 4, Project Zomboid (CPU intensive), Monster Hunter: World, and Monster Hunter Rise. It's Factorio stripped down to the essence of interweaving belts and sequencing multi-step construction of 'something or other.' It lacks the flavor and excitement of Factorio but it allows you to focus on the factory-organizing in essence—no aliens, no handcrafting. It also lacks the finiteness of resources, for better or worse.

My biggest complaint is that the target object keeps changing, so as soon as I get good at making one thing, the goal changes, and I have to rip out most of my factory and start building something quite different.

I like this game. It makes me feel good, even when I am sad, scared, or nervous. It does not remind me of the bees that make honey. I don't like honey. It is sticky and sweet and bad. It makes my fur sticky and my teeth hurt. I also fart a lot when I play this game. I don't know why. Maybe it is the fun. Or the shapes. Or the colors. Or the honey. I hope no one can smell my farts. But I can't help it. It is a thing that happens. A thing of shapes and colors and honey and farts.

Sometimes I play this game in my cave, where it is dark and quiet. I like to make shapes and colors that match the seasons. In spring, I make green and yellow shapes. In summer, I make blue and red shapes. In autumn, I make orange and brown shapes. In winter, I make white and black shapes. I think they are pretty. But sometimes they are hard to see with my big eyes.

Sometimes I play this game outside, where it is bright and loud. I like to see the sun and the sky and the trees and the flowers. But I also have to watch out for the hunters and the traps and the cars and the dogs. They are scary. They make me run and hide and growl and scratch. They also make me fart more. I think they are mean. But sometimes they are easy to avoid with my big nose.

I wish I could play this game with other bears. I think they would like it too. But I don't know any other bears who play this game. Most bears are busy with other things, like eating and sleeping and mating and fighting. They don't have time for games. They also don't have computers. They are expensive and hard to use with big paws. I am lucky. I found my computer in a dumpster. It was broken, but I fixed it with some wires and some honey. I know I said I hate honey, but it is good for some things. Like fixing computers. And making farts.

Very fun, love the lack of limits! That really makes this game stand out compared to other resource management games. There is no pressure or resource limits, which allows you to really focus on just making the shapes and optimizing your builds.

I like logistics games. I've played all of them. At least probably the most popular. If I could relate this to something, I'd say Factorio minus realistic world and enemies. The equivalent 'resources' are not finite, but instead finding best spots where 'resources' (in particular, shape combinations) exist that benefit whatever particular goal you're trying to accomplish. In both, you're goal is to build the most efficient delivery of processed 'resources' (in particular, shape combinations) for an end goal.

What makes it not replayable for me is there's no 'sandbox' mode. I've had at least one issue (one is all it takes) where the game file became corrupt. I'd basically gotten to the point where you just level for new random shapes and basically my set up was automated. I am forced to go through the whole game from the beginning. The leveling is too repetitive for me and takes too long to have any desire to do over and over again. There needs to be a way to play the game with all the basic leveling/research given to you. If I want to play this over an over again, I want to be able to start where I left off and perhaps build something more efficient from the beginning with all the 'researched' things you get from leveling.

You know its an automation game, which I'm no expert in. So ill leave that kind of review of its ups and downs in that regard for the 100s of hours reviewers. However, out of the good few I've tried, this one has the most 'one more turn/shape' and relaxed feel to it. 

In factorio for instance I can feel overwhelmed and a little lost at times, and while Shapez is obviously very similar, making massive and impressive feeling  builds fairly quickly, the next goal is always provided and the tools/machines to do so are more limited and obvious in their purpose. Which takes away the 'what next?' feeling. Also not being eaten and having new bits of the factory destroyed is much more chill.

I will hit the wall with factorio and think "ill go relax with with some Shapez" which so far, is a feeling no other Automation game has provided. Well worth the asking price.

An addictive puzzle/factory game that scratches the itch for optimization, efficiency and problem solving with complex production chains. Minimalist visuals, relaxing music and good controls in a seemingly endless world that fuel a constant need to improve the layout of a production chain.

Mine, cut, rotate, mix, colorize and merge shapes to complete the requested shape and advance to the next level. Shapes become more complex and your production lines will expand exponentially. Optimize with upgrades so every belt or machine performs its task faster and more efficiently.

This game triggers my OCD in a pleasant way as time flies by without notice.

After playing around a bit on shapez.io, which mostly is the same version, I bought the game on steam. First of all I was pleasantly surprised, that i could import my progress from the browser version.
Overall a very chill and relaxing game for tinkering around with your factory. I really like the concept of not much resource management with just flow optimization in a simplistic art style without any clutter.
The controls are a bit wonky from time to time, but they work fine overall. Finding the right merger in the correct orientation doesn't go as smooth form the hand as I'd desire, but I'm not sure, if there is a significant better solution.
Performance should be further improved as at least for my current factories (which are still operating for lvl4 and lvl5-upgrades) it does not run as good as I'd wish.
Later down the line there might be some depth missing due to the lack of more in depth production chains, but I'm more than happy with the current state.

In conclusion I can fully recommend the game in its current state, if you're not sure about it, just try out the demo on shapez.io.

While openly Factorio inspired, and I find Cracktorio, ekhm, Factorio rather all-consuming, this doesn't reach the same level at all.

I don't know if it's the limited number of machines, the constant changes to speed of them (so layouts that did work, stop producing full belts of stuff), the fact that there's just one item sink (like the rocket silo in Factorio) that everything needs to go in (so it's as much about managing space around the hub, as it is about constructing the factory), or is it the fact that you constantly are asked to produce new shapes while making old shapes useless (so you are tearing down large parts of the factory as it's making useless stuff)...

It just feels like a slog, and doesn't give the sense of progression, even when new machines and mechanics are rewards for completing new levels.

Maybe the freeplay is more fun, but I just can't bring myself to play long enough to unlock it, and after 10h, I think I gave it a fair shake.

Alt-tabbing creates multiple instances of the game on the taskbar in Windows 11. Closing the game doesn't resolve the issue, only main tab closes while the other tabs continue to persist. Doesn't appear to have a fix other than some janky workarounds mentioned in the forums.

As a fan of automation games, I really enjoyed this one. At first it seemed strange to me, not having any cost to build, but I realized that resource management isn't the point of this game. It's really about using automation to build more and more complex shapes, and doing it efficiently enough so that you don't have to wait for days to achieve a goal. Any minor annoyances with game mechanics were easily overcome with the use of mods. My only complaint is that Shapez has limited replayability, at least for me. Once I figured out how to create the shapes needed for all the goals, the game felt pointless. However, I still put a lot of hours into it and it was well worth the low price point.

I’ve already poured more than eight hours into this game and I cannot stop. It’s so much fun. It’s basically “Factorio“, minus all the parts that annoyed me. You get a randomly-generated map, with shape and color “resources”, and then you extract them, transport them along conveyor belts, and combine them into all sorts of things to climb levels and unlock upgrades. It’s amazing to me how such a simple concept can be so addictive. And best of all, it’s open source. There’s a vibrant community out there developing mods for it. They’re also beta-testing a sequel, “shapez 2”, which looks like it’s going to be 3D. I couldn’t more highly recommend this. This has become my new “fidget game” for keeping my hands busy while I listen to YouTube videos.

I play a lot of factory games and was a bit hesitant on Shapez.io at first but this has some unique approaches approaches to factory building that I wish other games would borrow from. Shapez sets very clear objectives for you that flow from one step to another. You'll start to reuse parts of your existing design based on the current objective and you start to develop 'megafactories' very quickly. Within 2-3 hours of my first run that would have taken me 20 hours or more on my first Factorio run. 

It is rather lacking in QOL features. I don't know what engine it uses but it appears to be dated and limited. Controller support exists but its not a great experience. I haven't played much so my factory is rather small, but the game has been running very smoothly so far.

To preface this review, shapez is a fine game. I love that it is open-source software, and I firmly believe that more games could benefit from following that model.

My issues all arise from the UI of shapez. I personally couldn't come to terms with these design decisions. Towards the end of my playtime, building and planning began to feel like a chore.

The first thing I noticed was the locking of copy/paste until level 12. It feels repetitive to make any optimizations/expansions before this, as you have to manually place each building repeatedly.

Navigating the variants of each building feels like battling the game. You press the hotkey for the building, then press "T" until the desired version is selected. However, the version that initially pops up when pressing the hotkey is determined by the last used version. This leads to pressing "T" a variable number of times. Creating pathways using the same structure in different versions is slow because you have to manually confirm each version change. An alternative is to use the pipette, but this requires you to have previously placed the building in the desired orientation and version.

Planning out long paths is made challenging. If you zoom out to check which direction to build next, your planned progress is erased. If you zoom in to verify that pathways align, your planned progress is erased. This results in either planning the entire path zoomed in or fixing any mistakes manually after planning (and ignoring any misalignment issues).

If you don't mind these design decisions, shapez is a great game concept. It offers a lot of depth in factory management and production. Unfortunately, it just was not for me.

It's not a factory automation game. It's a puzzle solver with an automation mechanic. I played for 60+ hrs. I loved it to start with, but it quickly became frustrating and repetitive. Once you build a single machine to make a shape, you're basically done. The rest is just copy & paste upscaling to make more of that shape. Many of the required shapes are one offs - you can delete that part of the factory once you've reached the required quantity. Too much unconnected puzzle solving, not enough automation and optimisation. There is little reward in building a large factory. You can just build a small factory and go play something else while it crunches out the quantity.  It lacks a natural flow of complexity where you use early factory to help with production in mid to late factory. I would've loved to love this game, but I just couldn't do it.

This is the game that got me interested in automation/factory games.

[hr][/hr]
The game world is a procedurally generated field populated with deposits of various grey shapes and the colours red, blue, green.
You mine shapes and transport them with conveyor belts to the Hub for collection.
As the game progresses, the type of shapes to deliver to the Hub change, and as you fulfil the deliveries, you gain more tools to manipulate the shapes delivered.
The tools enable you to blend colours, and cut, rotate, colour, and combine the shapes into what is needed by the Hub. 

[hr][/hr]
What used to keep me away from most games like this was the tension of having to monitor your resource usage, and/or time management.
Limited time and resources gets me worried about losing precious materials and opportunities forever.
An aspect i really enjoy about Shapez.io is that the gameplay avoids these stressors, allowing me more freedom to play at my own pace.
There isn't any time limit to beat.
The resources you mine do not get depleted.
This allows one to play without worrying about the cost of building and destroying components of one's delivery system, so you can play around, modify, and optimise your delivery system to your heart's content.
[hr][/hr]
It has a neat, minimalist graphical design I enjoy. The inclusion of a dark mode is very nice.
I don't really care about the music one way or the other, it's not my style, but i guess it is suitable as a background.

[hr][/hr]
Building the sprawling network of conveyor belts and machines, and discovering creative ways of optimising your design - both visually and  logistically - is very addictive and enjoyable.
I highly recommend this game.

I don’t have a lot of experience with automation games, and I’ve found those I have tried to be very “hit & miss”. After multiple attempts I just couldn’t get on with Factorio, but I took to Dyson Sphere Program and Satisfactory immediately and now consider both of those amongst my all-time favourite games. As such, I’m always on the lookout for games with that type of gameplay loop.

Shapez uses a clean and simple interface to take shapes from sources laid out on a large map, process them in some way and deposit them into a central collector using belts. Seems simple enough, but using the methods available, such as cutting, rotating, colouring and stacking, a vast array of intricate shapes can be produced.

The games uses a progression system of depositing different shapes in quantity to unlock additional tools to create shapes of increasing complexity. Unlike the previously mentioned games, there are no time limits, resource restrictions or currencies to be carefully managed. It’s simply the player, the tools and that brilliant soundtrack.

I wasn’t long into the free demo before I decided to buy the full game and it’s soundtrack. It hooked me from the start. Once into the main game I continued with my spaghetti of belts transporting my shapes all over the place, eventually ending up in the central hub by some miracle. Then I discovered ways to create elegant and efficient systems that could be easily copied, like quality pasta (see what I did there?), and it felt like I was playing a different game. Experts of these kinds of games may work that way from the start, but for me it was a breath of fresh air and really opened the game up.

I’ve found Shapez to be an interesting, enjoyable and relaxing experience, with a soundtrack that perfectly compliments a game such as this, and recommend it to anyone interested in automation or logic puzzles. It’s also priced very reasonably.

Overall, shapez is a creative and satisfying game, making the most of its simple premise. It was always satisfying to create complex multi-part shapes from such simple beginnings. I don't think it is one I'll play often due to it feeling like a slog at times, but it was certainly enjoyable to play through the levels the first time.

Standout qualities:
 - Satisfying progression through the levelling system
 - Easy to learn
 - Becomes suitably puzzling to match each level requirement with their unique designs,
      including space and resource 'supply and demand' challenges
 - Simple and clear interface that looks neat
 - Gentle yet elegant sound design

Some shortcomings:
 - Becomes quite repetitive, especially once you know efficient and compact designs. Replay value is low.
 - Given the above, the blueprint feature unlocks far too late in the progression. Manual labour required.
 - While the music is good and relaxing, it can get repetitive and dull in time.

So, I was watching YouTube and stumbled upon a random video of Factorio. I really wanted to play something like that, so I searched on Google for a browser game and found Factory Idle. It was quite fun, but it required a lot of waiting time. I kept on Googling and searching until I started to feel desperate. However, I finally found the web test version of the game, and it was incredibly enjoyable. As soon as I saw that it was available on Steam, I went ahead and bought the game, along with any related DLC and the soundtrack, to support the developer. The idea of providing a web test version of the game was amazing, and I truly loved it! Even if the game was ten times its price, I would still have bought it.

I've spent six hours playing, and it has been really fun and mind-bending. I particularly enjoy zooming out and admiring the amazing factory I've created in the game.

Overall, I would rate it 10/10. I highly recommend it.

A nice little game, at first a decent pass-time, but after a way it gets boring. You can copy-paste blocks, but you have to pay for it (with previously collected ressources), which is an odd design choice. As a result, you end up building the same "feed-two-ressources-via-splitting-conveyor-belts-to-eight-merge-devices" arrays over and over and over again, and playing becomes a chore. After a while, the number of objects to produce to finish a level becomes so insanely big that you have the choice between two boring options :
- Construct arrays of 16 or 32-merge devices for each step of the production, which is an interminable chore (remember, you can't copy)
- Construct everything with arrays of 8, and then let the game run while you're doing something else
But still, for a game in the 10$ price range, it's ok, because the first part of the game is rather fun.

Factory game like Factorio but without inventory management. What's there not to like?

You wouldn't be completely off base calling this "Factorio Lite," but that's also not giving this game nearly enough credit.
While shapez.io is firmly planted in the same genre of automation and system design, it emphasizes different aspects of factory building and manages to stay totally relevant and fun, even if you're a Factorio pro. Some of the limitations and realism of Factorio have been foregone, but instead of making the game feel weak or under-featured, it just enables you to diver deeper into designs and strategies that are too unwieldy to face head on in Factorio.

Especially at this price point, shapez.io is an absolute must-have. It's just ridiculously good.

Basically a super casual version of Satisfactory / factorio but without the compounding requirement. Such as "make 1 part... ok now use 3 of that part to make 1 of these... ok now you 5 of that part to make 1 of these.. now use 2 of that part to make 1 of these. " etc. 

This game is more about making something new every time from scratch. Which is honestly a breath of fresh air. Some items or "shapes" can be useful in multiple areas or entire factories can be repurposed when a new shape is requires and you were already making something that will help you build the new shape. 

The only downside is the game suffers from slight stability issues beyond level 20. prior to that I was able to let the game run while I was sleeping but after my map become more populated the game becomes frozen if my monitors go to sleep and I have to reset it when I come back. It does seem to maintain counting shapes while it looks frozen though so its a milk annoyance. The game also states its running in 144fps on my screen but I dont feel like it really is. Its not as crisp as I am used to. 

That aside. The game is definitely addictive and I will for sure be picking up the sequel when it comes out.

This game is very chill and relaxing. There is absolutely no pressure to get anything done, so you can just play around with the mechanics as you unlock them and figure out new ways to utilise then. I don't really have too much else to say, it's a pretty good game.

I do have one issue though. The colour name for magenta is inconsistent. I'm pretty sure anywhere you look in the game, it will tell you it's magenta, but when you go to create a marker, you can't use the letter "m" for magenta, you have to use "p" for purple. It won't matter that much for most people, but I'm weird and type them out by hand sometimes, and I thought I could follow the pattern, until magenta didn't work.

TL;DR

I want to like this game, I really do, but there are so many QoL features missing that make me want to play other games that accomplish what Shapez.io is trying to do. Building your base is not fun at later stages due to in-game features that seem more like roadblocks than tools to help you progress.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On it's own, Shapez is fun until the base and quantities start to get bigger. The motivation to keep going is to accomplish the goal of whatever shape is being asked of you.

That's a fine motivation for the first 10-12 shapez, but once you hit 17ish and have unlocked most of the buildings, it starts to become more of a chore than it is an actual game. Ultimately, you are limited to 16 belts of whatever is being asked because of the input capacity of the hub. Belt speed can be upgraded, but there is no reason to have more than 16 belts of a particular shape because it can't be delivered.

Put simply, building your base is not fun. I would hardly even call it a base because of how much changes from level to level. The game does not encourage you to use existing infrastructure to make a product. Everything must be catered to the shape being requested by the hub. It almost seems that this game should have been instanced in some sort of campaign with preset layouts on a restricted map for each level rather than being an open world resource production simulator.

After each level, you need to tear down and replace your base as needed manually or with copy/paste command that is unlocked later. I am going to avoid the word "Blueprint" because you never really have a blueprint to reference. It's just part of the base you made and are copying over. That's an important distinction because whatever you are looking to copy MUST be made in your base at least once in the save you are in before you can copy/paste. There is no library of copies, so pick one that is already in your base, make what you need in the moment, or put them far away with a way marker to compensate. The cost to copy is a nice touch and, in my opinion, mitigates any issues that a free blueprint library would bring, but the surrounding mechanics don't make it easy to take advantage of this. 

A lot of small QoL features could make this game much more enjoyable and more engaging such as...
-being able to see belt direction when zoomed out along with I/O of buildings
-mirroring copied items (turns in belts are the greatest offender)
-the aforementioned library of patterns/copied items
-cutting stacked objects remaining small instead of returning to normal size
-some building improvements like a placable delivery hub, quad painter having it's own on/off buttons, or better transport than belts across the map.
-wires. I personally didn't get far enough to see a good use for them other than turning on the multi-painter, but a lot of it seems needlessly complicated.

The game has mod support which probably fixes a lot of these issues, but I question why they weren't added to the game to begin with. I see the similar issues starting to pop up in the dev log of shapez 2. Idk what the dev is going for, but I can think of 3 or 4 other games that does what shapez is trying to do better while keeping players motivated to progress. Not saying that shapez should be copying these other games, but if it expanded on what it already has and improved some of its existing features, I believe it could be something special. Best of luck with wherever this project goes.

Factorio Lite

[h1]What is Shapez?[/h1]

Shapez is best described as a combination of automation and puzzle. While there are some similarities to Factorio, it is far more on the casual and slow-pace side of things. Each level gives you a certain shape that you have to combine from three different colors and 4 different shapes. As you progress, the required shapes get more complex.

[h1]Who is Shapez for?[/h1]

If you’re looking for a causal automation-puzzle that could also be played as an idle game in the background, Shapez is a good pick-up for you. If you’re looking for a more action-heavy game, this game isn’t for you.

[h1]Are there annoying/negative aspects I should know about?[/h1]

Some game mechanics aren’t really explained in the game, making it somewhat annoying to understand how to get certain shapes. Also, after level 26, every new level has a randomized shape required to advance. So while you could keep on playing after level 26, it does get stale fairly quickly.

[h1]Should I buy Shapez?[/h1]

Honestly, I recommend trying out the (shortish) demo version first. If you like the game, feel free to invest the 10 bucks. Or wait for one of the Steam sales and pick it up for 3 or 4 bucks. The Steam version gives you access to achievements as well as the option to connect to your Itch.io account and play the game inside your browser.

[h1]What games are similar to Shapez[/h1]

Final Upgrade, Mindustry, Factorio

Good game, but definitely not for everyone. 

I wouldn't necessarily call it Factorio lite, I think it's more akin to a more specialist game. There's no combat, no theme, no resource management, but what is left is more complex manufacturing and conveyor systems.

Attention all factory managers and production line supervisors, if you're looking for a puzzle game that truly captures the spirit of production and optimization, then Shapez is the game for you. This PC game, developed by Tobias Springer, offers a refreshing take on puzzle games by incorporating industrial design and optimization mechanics.

The gameplay of Shapez is simple, yet challenging. You are tasked with designing production lines to produce various shapes and colors. You start with basic shapes and colors, but as you progress, the production line becomes more complex and challenging. You will have to manage your resources efficiently and optimize your production lines to meet your production quotas.

One of the standout features of Shapez is its intuitive design. The interface is easy to use and understand, making it simple for anyone to jump in and start designing their own production lines. The game also includes an extensive tutorial system that will guide you through the different mechanics and concepts, ensuring that you are well-equipped to tackle the challenges that lie ahead.

As a factory manager, you know that optimization is the key to success. And Shapez understands this too. The game offers a variety of optimization tools to help you maximize your production output. You can automate your production lines, optimize your resource usage, and even set up custom workflows to ensure maximum efficiency.

But the real magic of Shapez lies in its replayability. With over 150 levels and endless possibilities for custom production line design, you'll find yourself constantly coming back to the game to improve your production output and beat your previous scores. And with the game's active modding community, there are always new challenges and optimizations to explore.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a puzzle game that will challenge your industrial design and optimization skills, Shapez is the game for you. With its intuitive design, extensive tutorial system, and endless replayability, it is a must-play for anyone looking to hone their production management skills. So what are you waiting for? Get designing, hit those quotas, and optimize your production output with Shapez!

Pretty fun, addicting, and mesmerizing game.  However, don't ever use their web UI.  I transferred one of my desktop saves to the web, spent several hours on it, and it destroyed my save.  At some point while I was playing, it seemed to lose my SSO token (kind of signed me out).  After logging back in, it re-awarded me levels.  But since some levels require one-off shapes that can stop supplying after clearing the level, I lost 6 levels.  So I would have had to replay them to proceed.

Compounding this issue is the fact that the game auto-saves every two minutes on top of your existing save.  Most games written in the past 10 years or so know better than this.  They auto save to a new save.  And most store manual saves separately from auto saves.  So instead of being able to recover before my save game corruption, I was left to either replay the 6 levels or revert to my desktop save.  Neither one is appealing anymore, knowing that the developer fails to utilize proper save game techniques.  

The lack of an "undo" feature is equally annoying, since a less frequent or separated auto save would allow a rewind.  I do understand that auto save can be disabled or have its frequency adjusted.  But there are no settings to separate and archive auto saves from manual saves.

Hopefully shapez 2 will have better save game functionality.  

In summary, the game itself is fun.  But the described major bug prevents me from recommending it to anyone else.  This is the first loss of progress I've had with a game that wasn't my own fault since my original Playstation (1) memory card stopped working when I was 40 hours into Final Fantasy VII.

A fantastic game to ease people into the automation/factory genre of games.

This game has no enemies, no power management, and no build costs. The only thing you do is build and watch your factories go. It's relaxing.. at first.

Don't let this game fool you. At first tasks might seem easy and simple, but overtime you'll see yourself building larger and more complex structures. You'll eventually need to figure out how to make stackable, expandable designs, you'll be tinkering to find out how to produce a shape, and you'll be asked to produce more and more to progress.

I almost would call this a "puzzle" game due to the complete lack of survival. All of your brain power goes into figuring out how to build increasingly complex machines, not the best way to set up defenses, or the right resources to focus on.

Overall, this is a great, simplistic factory game that I would recommend to pretty much anyone. It's perfect for older audiences that don't like stress, perfect for young audiences who want to use a bunch of brainpower, and everything in between. Great game!

At nearly 50hrs, I would say that this game has completely captured my intrigue. I am a huge fan of puzzle, resource management, and automation genre games and found this to be a great balance of casual and challenging. The game says in the beginning that it is not an idle game, but as someone who currently has to care for their injured partner, I really enjoyed the flexibility of the game to accommodate my need to occasionally walk away. No alarm bells or time sensitive alerts blaring in my ears while I helped around the house, and nothing was on fire when I returned! I know for some gamers, this may not be a plus, but it is for me.

I liked the upgrade system, I believe this helps keep the game adapt to the increasing challenge level as the game progresses. Early on in levels, the upgrade Shapez are often more challenging than the level up Shapez. I Think this is a good thing, as it challenges the player between tasks, and if upgrading was too easy, there would be no reason not to fully upgrade anything before pursing level ups. Great job devs on this balance!

I am currently on level 20, and will not spoil anything. It is the infamous "Shape" and it was the first time I had to look up a little help online to make something. I watched the official walk through with the dev and greatly enjoyed the passion behind the voice. This is truly a project with love and care behind it. In that video it is stated that Lvl20 is the "last level" and I certainly hope not! I plan to update this review once I am past it.
Hopefully there are new techniques to figure out and challenges ahead, because I could play this forever!

Overall, I would Strongly Recommend this to fans of the Automation/Resource Management/Casual 2D gaming community, as well as my friends. What sets this game apart is the pace. You can take your time, no rush to prep for invading swarms, or tragedies occurring. Just fun puzzles to solve with appealing graphics.

Thank you devs for your hard work, and thank you reader for your time! Can't wait for Shapez 2.
I love this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys factory games such as Factorio and Satisfactory. I think it's worth the money (and it's relatively cheap).

This game is utterly fantastic. Since picking it up the other day in a Bundle with Masterplan Tycoon, I completely neglected that game in favor of this. I share the creator's love/hate relationship with Factorio. I want to love that game but the complexity is sometimes overwhelming.

This game does everything Factorio does, but cleaner, simpler, and presented in steps that guide you in the right direction if the "sandbox" nature of it bogs you down with too many choices.

It's very easy to see what steps you need to take next, but there's no reason to rush through each level. And for someone like me with little kids who can easily distract you from gaming, it's a game that you can just get up from and not worry about getting attacked, running out of resources, or anything like that. 

I've found myself setting up manufacturing of one shape and then letting it run until I reach the next level, playing with my kids until it's time.

I can't think of a single complaint for this game, really.

[h1][b]Introduction[/b][/h1]
Shapez.io is an addictive and innovative factory building game that will keep you hooked for hours. The game features a simple but effective design that allows players to create complex production chains while being accessible to players of all skill levels.


[h1][b]Gameplay review - 8/10[/b][/h1]
The gameplay of Shapez.io is incredibly satisfying and engaging. Players must use different shapes and colors to create increasingly complex production lines, making it a great puzzle game. The game's sandbox mode allows for endless experimentation and creativity, while its campaign mode presents a series of increasingly challenging levels to complete. Overall, the gameplay is intuitive, fun, and rewarding.


[h1][b]Puzzle DLC - 8/10[/b][/h1]
The Puzzle DLC adds a whole new level of depth to the game, providing players with a series of challenging and thought-provoking puzzles that require a great deal of ingenuity to solve. The DLC is well-designed and seamlessly integrated into the base game, providing players with a seamless and enjoyable experience.


[h1][b]User-generated content review - 10/10[/b][/h1]
One of the most impressive aspects of Shapez.io is the amount of user-generated content available. Players can create and share their own levels, challenges, and production blocks with the community. This adds a level of creativity and replayability that is unmatched by many other games. The community has created some truly impressive content that is sure to keep players engaged for a long time.


[h1][b]Final review - 8.6/10[/b][/h1]
Shapez.io is a fantastic game that is both accessible and challenging. The gameplay is engaging and satisfying, and the addition of DLC packs and user-generated content adds even more value to the experience. Whether you're a fan of puzzle games or factory building games, Shapez.io is definitely worth checking out.

I don't really get what this game brings to the table. 

I think it attempts to prove that you can actually reduce all of the concrete concepts (like circuits) in games like Factorio down to just an abstract grind (with abstract shapes) and still have just as much fun. I don't think they're right.

In games like Factorio you at least get a sense that you're progressing toward something. In this game.... it's literally just the conveyor grind. 

It feels like one person created this and, that's commendable and impressive, but with all of the deep, rich, and interesting options out there (Factorio, Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program), I don't see what the point of playing this is.

Just my 2 cents.

[h1] Shapez [/h1]

Shapez is a top-down 2D automation and factory building game developed by Tobias Springer and published by tobspr Games and Doyoyo Games. The premise is simple; you extract materials and build factories to build and paint shapes, than deliver them to a delivery hub to progress to the next level or unlock upgrades. This map is seemingly infinite, fulled with varying nodes of shapes and colors to extract, with plenty of empty space to build your factories before you send the products off to the delivery hub.

This game is simple to learn and the further you get in, the harder your ingenuity and efficiency is tested. You start off a new game with the camera centered on the hub, and a simple task to accomplish before you progress to the next level. The levels progressively get harder and introduce new mechanics with each level you complete. Mechanics such as cutting, rotating, stacking, and painting will allow you to produce more complicated shapes. You can unlock upgrades that speed up processes like painting and cutting by delivering other unique shapes to the hub as well. The addition of the Puzzle DLC and mod support leaves plenty of other options on the table to play with. Replayability is not an issue at all with this one. 

There's really not to much I can say about this game. It's a simplistic game that's easy on the eyes. It sounds alright, and controls great. I suppose my only gripe would be the music that plays as you're in the game. It's the same song on a loop, which can get under your skin after awhile. Despite all of this, Shapez is a great, inexpensive little game for those looking for a mental workout.

Great 2d logistics/factory building. No cost to build, so you're free to experiment, destroy and build again to your heart's content. Being 2d there is no complexity of height which can go either way depending on your taste but what you get is unrestricted view and movement. It's very easy to fly in and out and get the lay of the land. And there's not much limit on space so you can decide how you want to be efficient. I liked to spread out so I could progress without having to fret over making extremely space efficient designs. 

The best part was getting blueprints (which allows you to copy and paste whole areas) rather early on in the game. So I could design machines: painteries, mixerizers, combinators, cutting stations. I could change and redesign them. When I needed a new complex product, I'd plop down blueprints of each these as needed and then do a little custom work to tie it all the together. Run a conveyor belt to the drop-off point. Done.

Making new designs was easy too. I'd make a modular segment and copy paste them together until it was enough big enough to match the throughput. New designs created in a fraction of the time.

It's a bit like Factorio or Satisfactory but pure logistics. There's nothing narrative about the products (like technology for survival/escape or goods to deliver to a corporation) but that was always an illusion. Shapes strips everything down to the essence of the genre.

Very fun factory builder, nice to not have to worry about any resource other than time & space. For all that it claims not to be an idle game it can scratch some of the same itches, as it can be very soothing to just sit and watch the numbers go up and the shapes get built without any input past the building stage. It can also be a fun puzzle game as you try and work out how to build the required factory in as little space as possible without covering useful resource squares. This is further proven with the puzzle dlc, when you want to challenge your puzzle solving skills without the worry of making your own factory, or want to try and stump the community with a tricky puzzle you thought of while making factories in the main game.

+ It's nice to tinker with assembly mechanics without monsters wrecking your work
+ There's good sense of progress; the unlocks are welcome, well-timed, and not really blocking progress
+ Unlike many 'puzzle games,' you're not playing new levels, you keep building
+ The efficiency goals provide enough extra depth to give you choices of 'what to do next'

My only gripes are minor, though they could arguably contribute to the game's character:
- The world is micro-random, to the point where there's no character or landmarks... Abstract, infinite, and lifeless.
- Coupled with the above, there's no real 'existential' challenge, short of how much time you care to spend on it. No monsters will ever invade, no resource constraints, and no cost of expanding too far (except using the clone function costs resources... An odd, if welcome design choice)

Overall a great value, great time killer, great tinker, and a reasonably intriguing engineering sandbox to boot. Would recommend to most gamers.

Shapez is a factory building game, no enemies, no cost to building, no time limits, you pretty much pick up and go and start building. Your goal is to deliver shapes to the main hub, starting as basic circles and squares, then half circles, then colored, and then mixes of the shapes, The game is pretty fun as you can build, destroy and then rebuild again, without any cost and not having to worry about anything. 

The major Con of the game is it does lose it luster after a while because once you starting building complex shapes, you then have to build other complex shapes, but if your someone who like Dyson or Factorio, and want a simpler version of those game, this is def the game for you!

It's like the most basic version of Factorio.  No base building, no tower defense, no shoot em' ups.  Just extract from the "mineral patch" and use belts and machines to manipulate the shapes and colors to get what is required.  You unlock more stuff which makes it easier to make your lines more efficient.  You'll want to tear down everything and rebuild, but you don't need to.  You have one collection "hub" and multiple "resource" patches.  If you finish an objective of a shaped colored recipe, you can still "collect" that and it will go towards upgrading things like belt speed, extraction speed, etc.  I got it for $4.  It's basically just a puzzle game.  It get a little more complex as you progress, obviously.  Recommended!

I'm going to go ahead and say this before I talk any further about this game.

If you are a beginner at any form of automation game and are struggling to grasp the basic fundamentals...
If you enjoy or are best at learning through problem solving and hands-on experiences, and absolutely adore logic puzzles...
Buy this game.
Buy it immediately, if you have the money to.

With that out of the way, shapez.io is a relatively simple automation game that gets increasingly complex as you continue to play it. There are a variety of shapes, as per the game's name, and your goal is to take apart, put together, color and fuse these shapes together and ship them to your hub in order to upgrade it and further your progression.

While there isn't any "main objective" outside of reaching the next level to my knowledge, the puzzles you're presented with when you play are incredibly engaging. Not only that, but they also provide you with a basic understanding and will test said understanding as you continue to go up in levels, adding tougher and tougher challenges to complete in order to unlock certain things.

One of the big things about it that really hammers down why I say this game is perfect for beginners is the things that are intentionally held back from the player at the beginning, such as blueprints and copy/paste being locked behind Level 12. This is what hit me with a realization that genuinely taught me something about these types of automation games - that being to start "messy".

What I mean by this is that you shouldn't concern yourself with making things look pretty or organized from the get-go - you should be setting down your foothold as soon as possible. Don't worry about the specifics - just get it working and start stockpiling as soon as you're able to. Once you have basic resources settled and stockpiled, that's when you can start to organize. Trying to "save yourself time later" will actually hurt you in the longrun due to the constant rebuilding and organizing, and you'll end up taking much longer to set up than you really should.

So. With all that said... You should play this game, especially if you really like automation or want to take your first steps into learning it. It's great.

Great game for those who enjoy Factorio and similar games.

Played it for 5 hours and progressed to getting storage unlocked. The gameplay is nice and simple to learn and resembles factory building games like factorio (just the building part). You basically extract shapes and colours from a 2D map and then cut/paint/stack them to form new "shapes" that the game asks you to build. You can build any kind of shapes that you want but need to build specific shapes the game asks to progress (and unlock more processors) or upgrade stuff like belt speed.

It starts out simple but it can get really challenging soon if you don't plan well enough. One nice thing is there is no cost involved for manually building and removing stuff - So you can start out as a noob and build crap but remove all that and make a proper factory later.

Overall opinion - Try it out if you get it on sale - Otherwise, better to wait for Shapez 2 which has just been announced and includes all the things in this game and more. If you want to get a hang of the gameplay, you can go to shapez.io on your browser and try out the demo version - That's how this got added to my wishlist.

I bought, downloaded and played this game sometime ago. Played 5 hours and then abandoned it because I lost interest in it. Then the other day I felt an unexplicable will of playing it again. After a couple of level it was immediately clear into my mind like initially I hadn't really understood it. I mean, I got into projects and more advanced levels, but I did not really master the game's tecniques. And I was even a Factorio player! Now every moment of the day I'm thinking about solving a problem in Shapez, and how to build machines. And I'm eager to finish working and eating to be able to play it. A feeling that, as a passionate PC player, I was not having since a long time. Shapez has really resuscitated my will to play videogames!
Try it if you like the building and thinking phase of Factorio, but get a little annoyed by the sometimes slow parts the game (low tech on early-game and moving through vast areas of the map with no trains).

Shapez is a casual factory/automation game that is about creating various shape/color combinations and delivering them to a hub in order to either increase your level or upgrade the speed of certain structures.  I got it for $3 or $4 when it was on sale and I think it is well worth it for anyone who likes factory management games.  Try out the free demo if you have any doubts.  Steam says I played it for 45 hours but some of that was definitely idle time where I had it running in the background.  There is a step up in complexity and challenge at level 20 that I found difficult.  I got to level 22 and I'm not sure if I will go further.  There is a Shapez sequel being developed that I look forward to playing as well.

Such a spectacular version of a factory game. Also the best game I've found to relax to. With no antagonists, you'd think that the game would get old fast, but the way that progression is set up and new things are constantly being unlocked, it always stays fresh and exciting. Not to mention that the puzzle DLC provides a whole new aspect of gameplay, as you must strive to create complicated shapes in a weird or compact way. Easily one of the best games I've ever played.

shapez is Factorio distilled down to its most basic gameplay loop. I really enjoy both games. I think shapez is likely to appeal to folks who get overwhelmed by all the detail and different objectives Factorio presents. In shapez, there is no real (world) exploration, no enemies to contend with, no resource exhaustion; only laying out the "circuitry" of extracting shapes and colors, manipulating them, and feeding the products into the hub to advance your progression. One way that shapez is superior is that every "recipe" is instantly understandable just by looking at the product. It's easy to play the game without needing to look up anything. The developer did a great job here and I think it's well worth playing.

It's Factorio but without the worry of resource management or attacking critters. Just pure design and infinite buildings (mostly).

If Factorio or games like it ever frustrate you because you enjoy the design part but are interrupted by the constantly running out of conveyor belts, this is the game for you.

Very nice soundtrack as well. Nobody will play this for the graphics, but that said, they're easy on the eyes. Obviously there's no real "technology tree" and everything is a lot more abstract, but it's great relaxing way to engage your brain and scratch that "intellectual stimulation" itch.

One thing I would like to see added is a visual indicator of which shapes on the "to do" list are currently being produced. Once they reach 1k, the decimals drop off and it's hard to see which ones are just being stored, and which ones are still being newly delivered.

I really enjoy games like this, But I found the mechanics past lvl 20 to be a little too complex. And I'm not even sure "complex" is the right word... The late game mechanics are just not intuitive. The mechanics are based on what feels like a glitch the Dev decided to keep and integrate as a mechanic. lol. I really enjoyed the early-game, but I can't recommend this game in its current state.

TL:DR - spent 77 hours getting to lvl 20(Some AFK hours to farm shapes). Game was fun, but I don't like the late game mechanics.

Edit: Replayed the game recently after seeing it has received multiple new updates. Still agree with my original stance. Specifically shape: "CbCuCbCu:Sr------:--CrSrCr:CwCwCwCw" the mechanics used to layer shapes is confusing and not fun.

Simple, fun, complex, and somewhat an idler game, Shapez is definitely a purchase I'm enjoying. You need to mix, match, cut, combine and rotate different shapes to make what is being requested. You'll also need to color combine your shapes. This is a simple game that gets complex the further you progress. 

There is also an upgrade mechanic that requires you to deliver so many of various shapes and color combinations. As these upgrades are achieved you'll be able to produce items faster. You'll slowly unlock better or more compact items to build your factory lines. This encourages you to really think about your factory designs. I find just trying to make things more compact or efficient is half the fun of this game.

I began playing this game on a lazy Sunday afternoon, after me and my wife had managed to put our newborn son to sleep and had some quiet time for myself. After what felt like a few hours I quit the game and rubbed my eyes, ready to make dinner. To my horror, though, I discovered that my son was 18 years old and was lugging a suitcase towards the door, getting ready to go to college.

I got up, laboriously reawakening my atrophied muscles and almost tripping on my years-long beard and the IV drip my family must have put me on at some point in the past. I opened my mouth to speak to him, but he stopped me with a gesture. With tears in his eyes, but also with a composure I could not help but be proud of, he said "No, father. The shapes must flow." Then he left home without looking back. My wife, carrying her own suitcase, followed him, sparing me a look full of tears and reproach.

I sat back down, stunned. I took a deep sigh and reopened the game.

I haven't seen any of them ever since.

Factory gaming distilled down into its barest form.  Satisfying, runs well, easily worth the price.  The shapes get pretty complex pretty quick, and building arrays and load balancing turns into a challenging exercise.

You have regular objectives and upgrades for your belts and buildings.  Objectives can be anything from coloring and assembling shapes to having to provide a production rate (shapes per second) of a specific shape.

The kicker is that all of your products have to fit into a 16-port hub in the center of the map, so upgrading belts and combining product lines becomes a necessity.
fun

I recommend because it's great fun, scratches that pattern and factory making itch. I'm tapping out at Tier 8 item for Belts upgrade though. The grey/blue circle with red on top and a white circle on top of that. The result of this one item has just turned me off the game entirely because it breaks its own rules.

I tried making the shape how my logic was going to make it, thinking top layers shrank as you used the merge tool. But to my surprise (wasnt really communicated in tutorials), the layers have 3d depth to them, so so if theres "space" underneath, the top layer just slots in, and doesnt actually shrink in size if theres space for it to fit in the same layer. Okay, interesting. Completely fine mechanic, shame the tutorial wasnt clear.

Then I look up the solution from others. And I recreate it to fully understand it. And this solution fundamentally is using the same kind of logic I am (different layer types, but layers on top of others where theres space to "drop down"), but this time for some unknown reason, it works.

I am monumentally frustrated at this point because I was loving this game, but in my eyes it has completely contradicted itself in what is possible in its own framework. So I have no interest in going futher because suddenly every new shape now carries the risk of "lol actually this is built in this dumb arbitrary way that doesnt follow the other rules".

I'm leaving a positive review because if whatever I'm experiencing "clicks" with another persons brain, theres no issue here. But from my PoV there is an annoying inconsistency in the rules of merging.

Great time sink for making your own puzzles to solve, then making them more streamlined. They just give you the tools to tackle the problems however you want. I love the freedom and hands off approach. Needs better zoom out features, but does what it needs to.

I wish i could recommend this game. I really like factory games where the task of automating something is the main focal point. This game does that really well, you have some shapes and colour and you need to create new shapes and colours from those. A simple start that gets expanded on with more complicated shapes and colours needed to be made.
However, what killed this game for me and stopped it being fun was there was nothing requiring me to think more than "How do i make this shape?". By this i mean, there was nothing forcing me to be more creative with my factory constructions. In other games the landscape can be fixed meaning you have a set space to work with, or there is something that is going to undo your work if you don't expand properly. In Shapez.io you don't have that fear or constraint. If you need to make a new shape you can just zoom out and look for a new area of the map to go to and build a new factory there piping the output back with no additional worries. 

For me this didn't quite scratch the itch. However, if you love factory games and want a gentler factory building experience then Shapez.io is likely the game for you. And definitely worth a look.

"It's not an idle game!" lol, sure, and I'm the queen of England. I built a great, expansive factory that'll give me all the parts I need in half an hour, do you think I want to build it a second time or do you think I wanna go get a drink?  Even duplicating stuff is a chore because the resource patches are funky in an annoying way, and you don't even get copy-paste until a ways into the game.  There's a lot of weird flexes in this game that feel unique for the sake of being unique, new features don't get unlocked fast enough to keep my attention, and it is NOT well optimized.

I think that's my summary in a nutshell:  "Weird flex."

I was marginal on whether to recommend it or not, but if I'm gonna play a game in this genre, I expect to solve some puzzles.  How do I do this efficiently?  How do I lay this out to do what I want?  Instead, I feel like I've been working... How do I paste this in a way that the belts don't get in the way all the time? Where can I find the thing I'm looking for on the annoying map? How can I line up belts across the freaking map? Which of the factories that the game tells me I should keep are actually uesless?  Yeah, I don't feel fulfilled.

Great game! Like a simplified and more relaxing version of Factorio!

One problem I have though...

Every time it asks for a new shape, it is in no way related to the previous one. Spend 3 hours automating half blue square, half yellow circles? Sucks, now it wants red pointy with a white square on top. Like now you either rip out everything you just worked for, or you leave it never to touch it again. This doesn't make me not want to play the game, but it does make things feel a little pointless every time you need a new shape. Plus since you have to start from scratch every time, you spend 3x as long building each factory than you do running it. Spend 2 hours automating one shape just to spend 10 minutes running it and then start over again.

A simple fix for this would be to ask for a new shape that's a modification of your old shape. That way you now have to expand and modify your factory, rather than abandon/erase it and start over.

This doesn't make me hate this game, but it does make me worry I'll drop it faster than Factorio since it has this constant frustration.

Edit: Yeah, I dropped it after like three days. Really annoying to make bigger and bigger factories and have to start from near scratch every time.

Shapez is a great automation game. The objective is fairly simple, create shapes and deliver them to the hub. As you level up the hub, you get new buildings allowing you to construct more complex shapes and more complex shapes are then required by the hub. I enjoyed this gameplay loop as it allows you to gradually learn how to optimize your production and find reusable, space efficient layouts. Once you get the hub to level 26, you have all the buildings unlocked and free-play mode begins, which is my favorite part of the game. This is due to the wires layer, which allows you to use logic gates and virtual processors to essentially program your machines, allowing you to a machine that automatically creates any shape required by the hub. Such a machine is called a MAM (Make Anything Machine), and I really enjoyed creating and optimizing mine. If you play Shapez, I highly recommend creating one and seeing how compact and efficient you can make it!

This is a tough one to review.  First, note that my playtime includes at least 150 hours of just letting the game run in the background.  In short, I do recommend the game.  It's fun to plan, optimize, and think through the various levels.  However, this game performs incredibly poorly when you start making a decent sized factory.  I have a 3080 Ti and an Ryzen 9 3900X with 64GB of 3200Mhz RAM and when I try to use the game's "copy" feature to copy anything more than a few hundred placed items, I can go to the restroom, call my parents, grab a bite to eat, and browse Reddit for a few minutes before the game catches up.  Without the copy/paste mechanic, this game becomes outright physically painful to play, requiring constantly holding down shift+wasd+LMB to place belts.  I actually had to go find my gamepad to alleviate some of the finger/hand pain I was experiencing.

I know this was developed by a solo developer, and it's far better than anything I could do, so I'm not trying to rag on the game at all.  I think with further development on game optimization and QOL improvements I would give this an unqualified positive rating, but as it stands, I give this an "enjoyable to get into, but ultimately fizzled out before getting all achievements".

Shapez is, for my money, the very definition of a factory builder.
There's no resource management, no crafting, no death or combat. What you do in this game is build factories as efficiently as possible, so that you can build more. A simple game, but one enjoyable enough for me to "complete" (depending on how you define that) numerous times.
If you like the pure building aspect of factory builders, get this game today.
If you like to optimize, get this game yesterday.

I enjoy the flow of this game. Its a good problem solving, efficiency chasing fun time. The way you break down the colors and shapes in to byte sized steps and then chain them together for the final product is a great way to scale the difficulty as the game progresses. I've played through from the beginning twice now. Great in full screen or windowed while you do something else at the same time. Cant wait to try this title out on the Steam Deck!

This game is up there as one of my favorites

It's not filled with action, it doesn't have any story to tell, and there's no sex appeal to speak of, it's pure gameplay. You take shapes, cut them up, color them, and splice them together with a variety of machines that you have to use to create given patterns. It looks a lot more complicated at first glance than it really is, once you take the time to understand how everything works. Sometimes you have to spend a lot of time designing a process, but once you get it down you can design a new one that's even more efficient. You can continue to make more and more efficient machines as the game gives you more advanced machines that make things easier while taking up less space and time.

This game is also very technical, so those looking for something simpler might not enjoy this one. However, if you enjoy a good puzzle, this one is right up your alley.

Simple yet effective visuals as well, makes things very easy to understand.

9/10

[h1] As relaxing as a factory building game can be. [/h1]

Shapez.io after awhile playing is a mess of conveyor belts, painters, rotators, and other parts all blurring by as you appease the giant hub in the center, asking for more.

[b]Good[/b] 
[list]
[*] The graphics are simple, and they need to be that way, it really helps me focus on the factory building.
[*] There's a dark mode, and my poor eyes really appreciated that.
[*] No enemies or mindless resource gathering for factory parts to distract from the main concept here.
[/list]

[b] Neutral [/b]
[list]
[*] The Music.  I'll be honest, i played this with the sound off because I was watching other stuff while playing. It's a good background game to have.
[/list]


[b] Bad [/b]
[list]
[*] It gets a little boring and repetitive after awhile. My way to solve this is to refactor everything to make it as efficient as possible, or start new factories with challenges.
[/list]

A fun game that goes from simple to complicated at a good pace but I wish the minimum Windows requirements didn't change. And I'm sure that they did because my PC use's Windows 7 when I started playing and it was FINE but now it says you need Windows 10 as a minimum :( .

Cheap and surprisingly deep under the surface, extracts the very core logistical concepts of factorio while streamlining it by removing resource requirements, transportation (mostly) and enemies. It's a simple premise, but it's honestly more of a brain breaker than factorio is due to the complexity and amount of steps required to make some of the later shapes, steps that far out number the most complex recipes in factorio. For a game about a no frills extraction of the puzzle aspect of automation, it's essentially perfect.

For the price its honestly a no brainer and a complete gem for those who like automation games.

Edit: I switched my review to negative as the game became enormously unstable for me at one point. I recently came back to it after several updates and the DLC, and so far everything seems stable. So Im tentatively returning this to a positive.

--------------------------

A visual programming game, in the same vein as Zachtronics games and Factorio, but stripped down to its core components.

Its an amazing game for the price, hours of tinkering to be had to solve all the shapes, get down your modular 'functions' optimise a neat little factory. Once youve completed the levels youll likely still have a bunch of tools youve barely used to further change things up.
 
I can see why some may prefer Factorio, but for me this is a much smoother experience. You dont have to worry about your resources running out, you dont have to think about Biters who arnt all that much of a threat short of starting a death world, you dont have to actually run around, or wait for anything to be built by bots. If any of these mechanics felt good to you then you may miss them, but for me they were largely just irritating and dragged out some of the more tedious aspects of the experience.

[A word of warning though, the requested level 26 shape is tough. As far as I can see it effectively has only one solution (and one line of symmetry for that solution.) I have no idea yet how Im going to work such shapes in to a fully automated factory.] 

Final and important point, this game is also open source as well, so you can feel free to poke around in its code. Which on first look appears to be very neatly laid out stuff, and fairly accessible if you are familiar with these things.
