Chill vibe automation sim, a factorio like but enough different, more abstract in nature to have distinctness and unique quality of its own.

"I like the idea of shapez.io more than I like playing it."

2 hours in I had these words prepared for my review. The game was cute but not interesting enough.

But I knew you unlocked something called wires later in the game, so I decided to keep playing until I unlocked that at least.

Needless to say I'm glad I did. While the shapes you need to produce become more and more complex, the thing that truly unleashed my enjoyment of this game was realizing I wasn't playing Factorio. Everything I built in the beginning was built with the expectation that my resources would eventually run out, and in this game they don't. Splitters everywhere is a bad practice in Factorio. Here it works surprisingly well.

There's all these tiny pitfalls you're likely to fall into if you come from Factorio. Spend some time designing your painting and stacker arrays. If your throughput isn't what you want, add more. Resources are infinite. You can spend a little time doing trial and error instead if breaking out your calculator. The map is infinite, there are no enemies and there's really no need to plan ahead. It's very "casual" in that regard.

But if you think that means there's no challenge then you're in for a surprise. 

Two shapes in particular are very weird and require you to more or less solve a puzzle in order to make them. 

Freeplay, which unlocks at level 26, starts generating random shapes for you to produce. You could make a new factory for each level... or you could spend time making a factory that can produce any shape with the power of logic, wires and shape analyzing. A "Make Anything Machine" or "MAM" for short. A very daunting task at first and when you finally get it working... shapez.io basically becomes an idle game. But watching your factory adapt and make the requested shapes without any input from you at all is incredibly satisfying.

There's also the speedrun stuff I guess... why do these factory games make me do this?
(Yeah they don't MAKE me do it, but having just one (1) achievement locked is torture for me so I "had" to.) Speedrunning isn't really why I like these games, but if you do, there's that as well.

There's mod stuff and puzzle DLC too. My playtime as of this review is for all achievements.
I can see myself returning to this game in the future, but for now I am done.

All in all, shapez.io is a factory game about producing and delivering shapes that takes clear inspiration from Factorio, but is in no way in its shadow.

Give it a solid chance, even if you think the earlygame is boring, and don't let Factorio habits influence you too much!

This game is a brilliantly simple yet deceptively complex zen version of Factorio. If that sounds like it might be up your alley, do yourself a favor and buy it right now.

Within the first hour, I was already forming ideas of how to make the perfect factory that could make any shape, and it felt like as the levels went on, they were designed to challenge my notions of how it would work. And for it, I fell that Shapez.io has pushed me to refine my mechanisms to perfection. It is really a perfect game to blow off some steam for a few hours but also still engage your brain, and I highly recommend it.

I think literally my only complaint is that performance is really not the best, but that's only noticeable when the whole screen is taken up by running machines (I'll be sure to update this review if it ever gets to acceptable levels).  

Also, it has a dark mode, so really what more could you ask for?
too much fun, I forgot what day it is

This game is amazing! Started out 2 years ago and it's received massive upgrades. I started out when wiring wasn't possible yet. Now we've got logic gates and amazing automation with that. The latest update also added modding, through which some major game play element upgrades are possible. It literally adds a ton of content and makes the game so much more playable with some super helpful lifestyle upgrades. In these 2 years I have seen an amazing game grow and I would fully recommend anyone to play it. You do need some dedication to learn to play, but if you're into Factorio-style games this is definitely a game you should give a chance!
Not your average action and fighting video game. Great for smart minds, designers, and engineers.

Very similar to Factorio, except there's no monsters, no character running around, and building stuff doesn't require any resources (sorta like creative mode). You still mine stuff, but it's used for the end products. It's addicting and fun!

My first thought, "This is the ETL tool Apache NiFi turned into a game!". Feels very inspired by Nifi's graphical style, spooky and a bit nerdy.

Simple premise, you have resources to "mine" and you extract, transform and load them into a master unit. As you start you're introduced to the small number of basic transform tools.

The real skill in this game is a) learning how to mix the tools to make the required shapes and colours and b) learning space and efficiency skills. You have finite space after each level you're often left with a bit of a twisty-turny mess of feed tubes, however you cannot just delete them as the game devs offer you extra goodies if you can leave feed tubes from previous levels in place to gather more transformed items. All this forces you to think carefully about the finite space you have to work and that's the real joy of this game. Logic puzzles and restrictions, superb challenges.

A great little game and the latest release also offers mods. As an added bonus if you are a coder and want some extra fun there is a whole API, Discord channel and github project that allows you to use Jscript tooling to design new levels and items. The game that just keeps giving!

Bought this to find another game that could scratch that Factorio/Satisfactory itch, and this MORE than delivers! It has a very thoughtful and intuitive tutorial, making it very easy to understand the basic concepts of how the game works while slowly building up complexity. More advanced automation games like Factorio are quite overwhelming for first time players, so this is a welcome change in the genre. Shapez.io is fairly simple in terms of design and game play, functioning more like a puzzle game. This means there's no rush, no fail state - you can just relax, take your time, and approach the puzzles at your own pace. I highly recommend Shapez.io, especially to people who her new to the factory automation genre.

This is probably one of the simplest factory-sims I've ever encountered. And in the process, one of the smoothest and most satisfying ones. The task is simple: There are all sorts of shapes scattered across the map, along with three colours. And then you will be tasked with producing a specific shape, in a specific colour, in a specific quantity. Once you finish that delivery, you unlock a new tool (up until level 20, at least, after which you get random shapes and get to try and figure out how to design a machine that will produce anything).

Oh, it starts out simple enough. Just supply some squares. Or maybe some circles, painted red. But then you get the ability to cut shapes in halves. Or quarters. Or pasting them together. Or layering them. And before you know of it, you've spent three hours muttering about colouring various shapes and how to optimise your cutting process...

This is a really great game! Best game i have played for building and optimizing product lines!

I have played Factorio, Satisfactory, Automachef, While True;learn, Dyson Sphere Program, Opus Magnum and SpaceChem.
And I will say that Shapez.io is my prefered game for a pure product line maker.

It is clean and lovely presented. The UI is minimalistic and nice. 
There is no hassle of product cost or external threat.  But at the same time, it has clear goals that are easy to understand and with many ways to solve.

Gameplay
You are making different chaps, where the end product are clearly defined. Seen as it is shapes with colors, it is quite easy to understand what to make, and very many ways of doing it. 
You are also using old products to upgrade. This makes old stuff still useful.
It is also nice that everything is always upgraded to the highest, so you don’t have to manually upgrade.

The copy function cost a specific produkt. This is a good way of doing it. Seen as it gives more meaning to your product and value to coping. The cost is not to high, so you can use the copy function for what you want, but at the same time, you will think before placing things around.
Gives more meaning to your placement.

The tools are logical and understandable, kutting, turning, coloring and so one. 

One can also mark the different factori lines, so it is easy and organiced where everything is placed.

This gives a great opportunity to optimize and make product lines that are very satisfying.



Will definitely recommend Shaper.io for people on the look out for a logic puzzler where you build and optimize production lines.

I recommend shapez.io to folks who enjoy logic or puzzle games, and crave the feeling of factory-building. So much easier to pick-up and play than heavier games like Factorio and Satisfactory. I've just begun playing my third or fourth play-through of shapez.io over the last few years, and each time has been a fresh new experience (initially because the game was still in-development). This time, with the new Shapez Industries mod, the game is feeling fresh again and I'm hungry for the challenge!

Obligatory "Steam should have neutral review options" comment.

I'm one of those who were attracted by Shapez.io because of its similarities with Factorio. To put it further, I can say that the only thing this game has that is similar to Factorio is its incremental nature (building stuff to get more stuff and using those stuff to get even more stuff) and maybe belts and splitters. 

Don't get me wrong. This game is far from being a bad game. It is very straightforward in his premise: you have shapes that you need to transform and then deliver them to the hub, located in the center of the map. New goals come with new levels, which involves producing other shapes. This requires more complex and better thought out "factories".

My problem with the game is that a lot of things seem meaningless. Sometimes you need to scrap all of your starter factory to produce new stuff, which is rather disappointing. Everything feels arbitrary and with no purpose rather than "transport it to the hub". Surely in Factorio you can also get rid of old factories, but sometimes it is not worth your time and it's better to just repurpose them. Shapez.io handles the shape thing in a very simplistic way that surely didn't appeal to my taste.

This could be fixed by adding more hubs that players could find around the map, or just having the ability of expanding your hub and consequently the input squares.

In resume, if you want a Factorio-like experience, you'll probably be disappointed. If you just want to relax with a simple and straightforward game with simple graphics, go for it.

One thing I find surprisingly great about the game: the stakes are *so low*. There's no "money", you can build a million conveyor belts to nowhere with zero problem. There's no time limit, and start with as much space as you could want. You can build intricate machines with extreme efficiency of inputs and outputs and no space wasted, but you can also get away with sloppy work at very little cost. This sense of freedom really gives you a chance to experiment and try interesting approaches to a problem. I find the game highly relaxing, but i also feel like I've been very "productive" while playing it.

To be honest, there's probably enough here to be worth the purchase if you're into this kind of game. I just can't heartily recommend it, because for me, the appeal evaporated so completely at a certain point. It's a very pure experience, but in that purity it distills away a lot of things that should keep a game like this interesting.

The first way this game is different from Factorio is that all the belts and things are free. There's no "you." You're just a camera, placing any belt or building wherever you feel like. And you don't need to produce anything to be able to do so. This is a fun choice. It's very freeing and relaxing. Your ability to fix your crappy factory isn't limited by the crappiness of your factory.

The other way this game is different is that everything you make is just arbitrary abstract shapes. At first, that seems fine. It's basically the same fact as not producing your own materials, right? Well, not really. What it boils down to is that every production line feels the same. You cut, you paint, you combine. You come up with a design for a combination line, then copy paste that wherever you need another one, which is everywhere. It doesn't need to be any different because it doesn't ever matter what the inputs or outputs are.  The basic schematic is always the same. Then you combine lines with identical schematics and eventually you have the thing you're trying to make.

It was around the third time I was making the same big setup to mix white pigment that I started to feel like I wasn't solving any problems anymore, and I could foresee no end to it. 

You do a little thinking when it comes to finding the best shape mines to use for whatever you need. You do a little thinking with load balancing. But with limitless space and resources, all you're really doing in scaling up the same simple factory patterns over and over.

Is this an inevitable artifact of making structures free? I don't think so. I think an interesting tech tree and varied production processes could result in a game with a lot more flavor and challenge, without turning the player's inventory into a cog in it's own machine.

shapez.io is a neat puzzle game where you are in control of mining a vast wasteland of odd shapes to appease the ever-hungry being known only as The Hub. Why are you doing it? What is this conveyor belt of oddities being used for? It's never really explained, but if The Hub wants 8,000 blue circles, it's time for you to find those round things, mine them and paint them blue. The learning curve of your new job is good until about level 20, and by then you're in too deep to quit.

Highly addictive, and you can also play it like an idle game if you don't mind watching a counter tick up very, very slowly to 25,000 sometimes.

Fun little game for some relaxing hours without any pressure and only goals you yourself want to reach.
especially recommend for any puzzle fan but also anyone else

Great game to start but once the game introduces shapes like the logo, everything you done up to then is thrown out the window and you have to fiddle with weird half shapes to get a piece floating on a different layer.  The game doesn't teach you this. It is boring and unintuitive.

Because shapez doesn't limit your building resources like say Factorio does, it plays very differently. It's about figuring out a good, scalable solution to your current predicament. There's no waiting around for resources to accumulate, which is great. The music will massage your very soul while you arrange an orderly machine of abstract production. This game is so close to perfect really its only issue is how quickly the experience is ultimately over. And also that the optimal way to play past a certain point is literally deleting everything from before. The construction space is virtually infinite and lacks terrain. Your only obstacle is your previous infrastructure, which when it stops being useful, you can just remove. That's kind of a bummer.

Vastly more relaxed than Factorio due to no manual harvesting nor enemies, but with infinite resources and focus on flow/ratios/efficiency of Satisfactory. Progress feels fast and fluid because each next level gives a new task. There is still a "tech tree" by way of optional upgrades to component speed.

Overall, absolutely wonderful. Charmingly clean graphics, tight building, nice music and controls. If it's available, I'll buy this again to play on a tablet.

Great game. Rather challenging and geared to the engineering mind set.  To me the ultimate goal is to engineer a super efficient "Make Anything Machine" which I've attempted twice already.  The first one was mediocre and would take up to two minutes to build a new shape.  But because of the limitless resources and sandbox like environment I was able to practice and figure out how to make more efficient designs so my second machine could turn over a new shape in 30 seconds.   As the game is open ended you make up your own mind what your final goals are.   The Puzzle DLC has been fun to work with as well.  Either working up user submitted puzzles or creating my own, I've been enjoying the challenge.

Fun game. I enjoyed building bigger and bigger machines along the way. I especially like that you can completely automate the factory with the wire circuits by the end. I have mine set to automatically alternate between 16 full streams of upgrade materials while the buffers fill. And then once they are sufficiently full, it switches to flooding those in on all 16 belts. It seems to take about 10 seconds for it to trigger the next level. Very satisfying to watch. 

The 30-minute speedrun achievement was really hard, but I was able to get it with a little help from AHK for some of the tedious parts.

Fun game idea, and some really fun rendering. That said, the game is quite clicky, and there are some real user interface issues. Rather than document these here, I'd just say that I think if the developer took a half-dozen new users and logged carefully while observing their run through the tutorials they'd find a number of opportunities for improvement. The tutorial is great at teaching how to use the "buildings", but less good at giving any kind of strategic guidance. I'm picking up the game for the third time after quitting twice: the only reason I'm still here is that a friend is playing and that encourages me to keep up a bit.

It's cool that the game is open source: if I had a bit more time I'd offer some fixes myself.

It is Factorio, but less. It is not "Factorio, but different", it is not "its own unique spin on Factorio". It's a feature stripped from Factorio and sold as its own game. It is what VR Missions is to Metal Gear Solid. It is that custom level where you stand still shooting bots in Counter-Strike. It is what the starting menu warm-up mode is to FIFA.

If you're not familiar with Factorio, go play Factorio.

If you are familiar with Factorio, shapez.io is not all bad. I give it a thumbs up after all. But be wary of these reviews, they are spinning the game in a very positive light. It is not just Factorio without the context, the resource management, the pollution, the danger, the difficulty, the player character. It is all those things, but that's not all. 

In Factorio, each material represents a resource. They require specific manufacturing steps to build more complex compounds and devices, allowing you to process further in the tech tree and thus the game.

In Shapez.io, there is the cutter, the stacker and the painter. That is all. Each is introduced in the 15-minute tutorial, and the rest of the game is cutting, stacking and painting. Any progress in the game is having more cutters, stackers and painters in conjunction.

Some reviewers are saying "there's endless complexity in the variations!" as some sort of replacement for the content found in Factorio. It's true, there are many variations. Each "block" is just the titular shapes after all. When playing the game you are asked to build quarter circles combined with a green square combined with a yellow star. Undoubtedly the mathematical possibilities of different shapes are astronomical. There is no complexity to it, though. Manufacturing any shape happens in a combination of cutters, stackers and painters. You might rotate a block differently, or stack from left to right instead of right to left, but the procedure is the same each time. 

This gigantic number of possible variations is of course achieved by having the blocks be entirely meaningless. You're not using them to build anything like in Factorio, they are simply "collected in your HUB", so you can open up the pause menu to view how many you have collected. You do get some missions that don't seem to do anything after the tutorial, and a level up mechanic, which basically just speeds up the game. Not "speed up" via unlocking features or abilities. Literally speed up by sending a multiplier to the game engine to run faster.

Because there is no context, no setting, no story, no character and no danger, there is also no incentive for the player. You could just leave the game running on its own, and you won't be any further along or in a more advantageous position if you spent the ten hours playing intensively. That might not matter to you, but it's worth mentioning.

That lead me to the dreaded conclusion: this is a game for people who like to "kill time". I don't like to kill time. I do it out of my own stupidity or laziness, but I don't seek it out. To me it's like saying "I like to burn money" or "I like to throw away food". I gain no enjoyment from it.

There is however something in this game that in my opinion pretty much justifies its existence: the Puzzle DLC. I should review it separately, but giving access to the Puzzle DLC is what makes this game worth getting. The Puzzle DLC is very self-explanatory, it's puzzles with limited resources, using the same mechanics familiar from Factorio. It truly is "a unique spin on the Factorio formula." So if you're buying this game, get it with the DLC. 

The base game might have some value in keeping your fingers occupied while listening to a podcast or something, but you could also just learn to knit. It's more engaging, more exciting, has more variety and you get socks or a nice hat out of it.

I really can't describe how satisfying it is watching all of your freshly made shapes rolling along the conveyor towards the end. This is an excellent factory simulator with simple but charming visuals and infinite variety. Even if you don't care about efficiency, I still recommend this game. The most fun I had was when I decided to create a random shape generator just for the heck of it. Not to mention the price tag is pretty cheap anyway, so just get the game!

This game is 100% my own special brand of autism. I have never liked a game design more. This is basically JUST the factory planning part of Factorio distilled into its purest form. Resources on the map are represented as various shapes and colors. You are tasked with arranging these raw resources into a specific pattern. It presents novel and interesting challenges consistently without being overwhelmingly complex or obtuse. The UI is clean and assists with ease of gameplay without getting in your way or being obtrusive. There are no limited resources, only map space and what your PC can handle simulating. Optimizing factories for efficiency, throughput, and size is pleasantly engaging but ultimately you have to think as hard as you want to think at any given moment. It is a very low stress but engaging game. I am hoping that they add some levels of complexity some day but overall this is a very lovely game. I am excited to get to the logic and programming portion of the game next.

Great game for content but not so great if you want to make things number efficient as possible.

Specifically the game doesn't do the super complex task of precalculating everything with timings well so framerate does affects stuff and slow things down at times. Its not just framerate, there's all sorts of bugs with numbers displayed not being accurate in all sorts of places so if you want to make some sort of factory and accurately calculate numbers... you simply cant. half of those problems might have unobvious workarounds (like just adding another part) but to me being forced to follow specific illogical routes just to circumvent a bug isn't really fun anymore when it comes to this type of game and i'm trying to be efficient with what i make.

Since it seems to get updates i probably wouldn't have not recommended this but, from what i saw, some bugs havent been fixed for a long time and ill assume the later they avoid fixing them the more likely itll break more existing stuff people made so i somewhat doubt those bugs will ever be fixed. 

Of course, if you dont care about reading displayed numbers, and just want to make it work, then its still a great game.

This is an incredible light-weight game that is way too overlooked.

What an amazing game this is. So simple, but so busy.
The goal here is to build a factory that produces all sorts of shapes in all sorts of colours. You can see the shapes as different food objects, or anything else you can picture.

The graphics are good. Good does not always have to mean realistic. Simplicity is a virtue too!

The game starts simple, and may seem dull at the beginning, but it gets more complicated overtime. You even have the possibility to build computers that automate everything, and create any shape you want.

I give Shapez.io a thumbs up for its carefully planned, slow escalation of introduction of factory building mechanics and its laser-focused attention on factory building. There are no distractions in Shapez.io, only the factory and the problem laid before you by the game. 
	You will enjoy Shapez.io if you like new logistic problems to be thrown at you in careful succession but don't enjoy dealing with the ramifications of your old work. In Shapez.io, your old factories can easily be deleted or forgotten by comparison to other logistic simulators. The game can be jumped in and out as easily as a pair of socks or a matchmaking game, with no spin-up to remember, "What was I doing before I quit last time?" The objectives are simple and you need not find your own goal.
	Shapez.io can be pronounced as Shapes, Shapez, or my personal favorite Sha-pezeo (saying the whole thing in one mouthful). Shapez.io is a colorful, minimalistic, obvious love poem to Factorio. So obvious in fact, that one of the loading screen tips of Shapez.io is "Play Factorio! It's my favorite game".

Best $5 I ever spent on Steam...have "finished" the game after playing for 100 hours.  It's a fun game that makes you think without the pressures of time limits or limits on material resources and the such.  You're given a shape and a ton of "deposits" of the basic parts needed to make it, and you need to figure out how to move the parts around, manipulate them, and put everything together into the finished product.   

If you're at all on the fence over this one, just buy it.

I used to play this game in the free browser version for a while, and figured the extra features of the paid version would be well worth the investment.

It's a very satisfying factory-type game with somewhat simple mechanics. You start out extracting simple shapes from your surroundings into your Hub, and slowly start to expand on what shapes you need, what you can do with those shapes, and those then give you rewards to help further expand your factory.

The shapes around your factory are randomly generated, which can either help or hinder your progress as finding the right shape source and how "perfect" that shape is determines how complicated your factories need to be, which then have knock-on effects on your throughput (your shapes per second on a given track), there are also paint colours you will have to extract but your throughput is usually determined on the colour source size rather than the random nature of the shapes.

The gradual way in which you unlock the features allow you to get accustomed to how they work, I've not yet unlocked all of the features of the game, but so far I've unlocked the ability to: Rotate, Delete, Cut, Stack, Colour, Merge Paints and Merge Tracks, which all have various configurations you can mess with to create compact yet complicated factories.

There is also a fleshed out wiki that has a bunch of design suggestions if you need advice, and plenty of YouTube videos on the optimisation of your factory. 

It's not as complicated as similar factory games, such as Factorio, Satisfactory, and so on, and doesn't demand a lot of computational power to run properly.

For what it is, it's an experience well worth the asking price.

I'd recommend this for some. I myself may continue to take it up. But I think overall the answer has to be a " not recommended " and I'll explain why.

The beginning, where you learn the ropes and unlock the stations -- the idea behind this game -- it's really fun, and challenging. Simple turn ins, in the 10s? Ok. After the tutorial stages, it gets interesting! What's this strange shape I'm supposed to turn in? It's a combination of 3 different mine-able shapes, you gotta decompile them, color parts differently (coloring requires some mixing too), rotate each piece into position, merge together, stack in order, etc etc. The core of this game, the puzzle and logistics behind creating a ' shapez ' , is genuinely really fun.

The part that sucks is ... I spent 10-15 minutes setting up the most complicated shape I've seen yet, that can't... really get too much more complicated with the limited number of shapes and colors in this game... and I'm producing like a quarter of the shape a second. I optimize somethings (split every mining path up a couple times, since the time-consuming is all these little stations, and I can now double those)... and bam, ~20 minutes, I've got this shape now coming out at .5 / sec. Oh wait, I don't need ~3k like last level, now I need 30k. Or 60k seconds, a hair under 17 hours. 

Well, I can do the entire process again. And again. and again. Now after an hour and 20 minutes of solving the same puzzle I've already done before, my wait is a mere 4 hours. At least I'll finally get a new puzzle! Only... after 6 upgrades, up to 1000, there are no new puzzles. It's the same shapes, over and over. That number of turn-ins is the only added difficulty, and scales into tens of millions. There's no new challenge of " how am I going to make this " and it's more like ... " how am I going to spend 20 hours making machines that make this shape, and still have to wait weeks before I can unlock the next difficulty, which is the exact same thing again, but my ramp speed will go from 8.4 to 8.5! " 

The beginning of this game is really great, the idea is really fun, and I feel like it has a lot of potential. I may leave it overnight a couple of times to unlock the simple upgrades, and then set up a couple lines for the campaign and leave it overnight for the next mission. I can't imagine trying to play it out by making the same ' shapez ' production line tens or hundreds of times, then still waiting hours, though. I feel like if the system replaced " the tens of thousands, to millions, of the same shape you have to turn in " to " several hundred to thousands of a constant variety of shapes " , ((which wouldn't seem hard to do?)) this could be a real game to get lost in! Instead it's in kind of a gray area of " a good game, but with some terrible implementation. "

/edit After playing some more, I think it does have some appeal like an idle game. If you can leave it overnight to crank the higher things, it's not so bad? I still wish it wasn't quite so necessary, but oh well.

This game is basically an alternate version of Factorio, so I'll just focus on the differences.

Shapez.io is like Factorio but without the following:
- Every placeable object is completely free to construct
- (you have no inventory since every building is free)
- Every 'ore' patch is infinite
- There are no obstacles or enemies or terrain

On the face of it, you might say 'well that sounds strictly easier than Factorio,' but: In this game there is no single 'assembler' building but rather multiple smaller buildings that do discrete assembly tasks, and going from raw resource to finished product can involve up to dozens of these tasks. It's like if someone 'opened up' the assembly buildings in Factorio and let you design your own. Also, there are hundreds of permutations of shapes instead of the dozens of craftable items in Factorio. You might say 'okay, we'll think of the circle shape as Iron,' but then - what is specifically the lower-left quadrant of the circle supposed to be? What if it's green? What if it's stacked on top of something else?

Basically, Shapez.io removes resource management and environmental challenge completely, and adds extra complexity in assembly and item variety. In the end I think the two are equally challenging, although I would suggest Factorio for players new to the factory-sim genre.

Shapez.io is a niche game, but it fills that niche incredibly well. It's an automation game that reduces the scope down purely to the conveyor belt logistics element, and then expands on that with numerous ways to interact with the belt objects - in this case, shapes.

You rotate, cut, reassemble, stack and paint shapes to make whatever the goal is for the level, plus various other shapes that are needed for upgrades. And, really, that's the game. There's not much more to it than that...

...except for the steadily increasing complexity of the shapes, plus the constantly expanding array of tools at your disposal. The game has a perfect learning curve, starting you off with the absolute bare minimum amount of tools you need. When a new one is unlocked, you get an explanation and demonstration, and the next shape or one coming up soon after will require some simple use of your new tool.

The game is essentially a sandbox with objectives; you have infinite amounts of every building, all resources are infinite, and the map scales infinitely in size. And that's the greatest strength of Shapez.io; it goes at your pace. Experimentation is free, and it's easy to naturally play around and discover ways to make your factory more efficient in size or speed. The game gently nudges you towards doing better by steadily increasing the number of shapes per level, but it's still ultimately up to you how optimized it needs to be.

After level 26, you get your final set of tools, so the game issues you one final challenge: build a factory that can make ANY requested shape, without needing to be changed; each subsequent level requires a randomly-generated shape, so doing it manually is simply no longer practical. Figuring out how to do it is a doozy, but it's a fantastic final challenge to the player to really test what they've learned.

Fantastic game if you like the genre. And it's nice to see more open-source games too.

Considering the price point of this title, there is very little reason not to buy it right now. If you have ever played Factorio or simply don't have the money to buy Factorio, shapez.io will scratch the same itch quite well with a much simpler art style.

My only single gripe with the game is that you have a 4x4 box which all of your shapes will be delivered to and the game encourages you to never delete your old factories. This creates a massive issue within the first half hour at most in which there isn't enough space to keep your old factories which leads you to deleting them anyway and redesigning them.

In Factorio you can have similar issues of spacing, but this rarely matters in the long run if due to there not being one single "hub" in which all of your resources need to be poured; just other factories in which you can choose the location of. In shazpez.io this is not possible and can create some extremely frustrating situations in which you need to redesign literally everything you have created over a certain period of time just to allow for a new item to enter the hub.

This becomes even more infuriating when you then need access to the old item, the one in which you had to disconnect or destroy the factory of as to make room, to progress later in the game (usually in the form of combining the old item with a new one as to continue).

This sounds like an oddly specific gripe to have, but it impacts the game to a massive degree and can lead to dozens if not hundreds of wasted hours in the long run simply because you built your factory off by a single tile.

But, nonetheless, for under $10, even with this issue, I'm amazed that you haven't bought the game yet. It is more than worth it!

It really hurts me to give this game a negative review, simply because the developer seems like a really nice guy, and i had high expectations for this game, but in its current state, I cannot recommend it if you have a crippling addiction to build stuff as perfect as possible. There are three big problems I have:

1: When you build something and have not unlocked every Tool/Variation of tools yet, you always build stuff knowing that you will have to tear it down later because there will be better ways to do it available. Games like Factorio handle this in a (imo) much better way because the only types of upgrades you get for existing machinery are speed upgrades. New machinery always either belong to different game areas entirely or does not allow you to suddenly half the size of your creation by rebuilding it entirely. This constant "throwing away" of your builds really makes it feel like your first (im guessing) 15-20 hours of gameplay really have no use at all.

2: The developer made choice to lock the copy/paste/blueprint functionality to only be accessible later in game. I dont really mind this for blueprints, but not being able to copy and paste in a "sandbox" game really sucks. Building stuff, especially in tighter spaces was made extremely tedious due to not being able to just shift your builds over by a few spaces when needed. You are forced to build your stuff over and over again until it fits.

3: Most of the machines you build consist of 30% actual machinery and 70% belt balancing and other logistic stuff. This wouldnt be that big of a deal if it werent for the fact that all of the balancing stuff is pretty much the same in every single production line you build - again, a big help here would be a copy/paste functionality unlocked from the start. I also feel like this issue would be easily fixed by just allowing loading a belt from more than one side at once, like basically every other game in this genre, but that would probably also bring a lot of other design decisions with it that I am not able to consinder so take this point with a bit of a grain of salt.

Now for the good stuff:
- This game really nails its visuals.
- Very good balance between simplicity and mastery of tje mechanics (think: "easy to learn, hard to master") 
- Good introduction to the Genre
- The puzzles mode in the DLC is pretty unique and actually a lot more fun to play

Again, this review probably does not affect most of the players, so you will have to decide this for yourself. I also looked over some other issues, like poor performance due to the game being coded in JavaScript (which isn't necessarily always bad, but certainly not the choice for a game of this kind) and some other small stuff, that didn't really affect my enjoyment in any big way. In any way, I still have to commend the developer for making a daunting genre accessible for a lot more people and serving as a good introduction.

This is just a fantastic game. It's like all those other factory games (which are fun), but it chills it all way out. In other games, your machines will get jammed up with the wrong inputs, and in this game, they just peacefully take it in and ignore it. Well, one exception I wish they'd change here: if paint gets in your shape machines, they stop cold. I don't like that. But overall, the game makes everything as chill as possible (you have unlimited machines, nothing costs any money, space is limitless, and you can delete at will, and even - eventually - copy and paste), while still giving you the tools and freedom to solve the puzzle of how to produce these increasingly complex shapes. Two thumbs up.

Excellent. And open source! The only thing I'd change is add something that helps with space, such as actual modules that shrink a selected mini factory into a single unit. The tips on the loading screen imply there's a feature like that, but I'm either an idiot and can't find it or it's not implemented yet.

Also there are a few computer resource/lag issues, but they're pretty light considering the nature of the game so I can't really fault the devs for that, just something to be aware of as you get further into the game and your factory gets more elaborate. If you're having trouble with it hanging and crashing, try launching outside of Steam, that helped me significantly. Only downside is that it doesn't recognize the DLC if you launch it that way.

General tip: Save often, exporting the save file in case it gets corrupted. Also very helpful to do if you want to try something but want to be able to revert easily if it doesn't work out well.

Overall, 10/10. I can't stop playing, even though I've "beaten" the game I can't stop optimizing my build to switch shapes faster.

The best game I've ever bought on steam! Every other autistic game of [i]essentially[/i] numbers will ultimately reveal some sort of internal inconsistency or counterintuitive aspect of the core game design that'll end up tarding you out completely off it searching for the next. The buck stopped here. 

It's too simple to dilute but progressively complex enough to seemingly have no drop off in fun. The problem is trying to stop playing this game, or keeping track of how much time you've actually sat there playing. Initially I tried rushing through what I thought was the tutorial to unlock everything and then dive in. Come to realize the gameplay itself was so entertaining for certain people like me I couldn't pull away. 

The only weird thing I noticed and others seemed to comment too was level 20. It's the 1st time you change the size of the shape but it's done through a stacking process that is honestly easier to just look up the principle. 

Every single engineering/simulation game I've purchased on steam was to find [b]THIS[/b] game. If you search for those types of games, watch the trailer for this one. It's honestly exactly as good as it looks, and I cannot predict this game beginning to bore.

The design puzzles get satisfyingly deep quite quickly (or, quite quickly once I did a few restarts out of embarrassment at how obtuse my earlier starts were). Game is a decent factory game with a touch of puzzle solving (how to make different shape combinations).  Half the fun is trying to maximize your layout.  The game progress is pretty good early on but can be a bit frustrating later on (since many upgrade/new buildings are locked behind progression)

There are however some issues/limitations that reduce its overall quality: namely how stacking/layering complex shapes works (or doesn't work / not very intuitive); how the conveyor belt "smart" path finding can be frustrating (currently it can override exist conveyors, or ignores the path you planned); and lack of the ability to 'undo' things, especially after placing a copy/paste/blueprint wrong.

However the game is still a lot of fun and enjoyable.  If you like factory games, you'll probably enjoy this too.

Note: If you buy the game, look at the steam guides for upscaling factory layouts.  It will really help you in the game.

I bought this game two days ago and I've so far put in 22 hours. This is ridiculous. When I first bought it I thought I would give it a quick try before jumping back into Rimworld, and then seven hours passed. It's very fun but don't expect to be able to stop.

This is a great game for anyone who enjoys puzzles.  The large amount of agency it gives the player - combined with relatively simple ideas and mechanics - creates an elegant challenge that will satisfy players of any skill level.  It is both intriguing and relaxing in ways few games are.

In a way, shapez.io is quite straightforward:  You design machines that build shapes, and get those shapes to the central Hub.  The game presents the players with tools, a goal, and very little hand-holding, which is both rare and admirable in modern puzzles.  This creates a wonderful space where the player is able to challenge themselves to make smaller, better, faster machines at their own pace, and to their own satisfaction.  I sometimes found it fun and rewarding to look over old designs with new ideas and find ways to optimize; I sometimes found it fun to try a new idea from scratch; and since the restrictions came from the base mechanics, I never felt overly frustrated or unfairly blocked.

Each time I found myself satisfied in my understanding, the game threw a curve ball:  A new tool with new possibilities, or a new shape combination I hadn't considered, and by the end it had evolved into something that it had been leading up to from the start, but was also somehow surprising and unexpected.  All the way until the moment I stopped playing I was solving mini puzzles in new goals I had created for myself.

I played this for a few days and am immensely satisfied with my time.  If you like puzzles, you're going to love shapez.io

Great game. Just look at the screenshots and ask yourself if you find this kind of thing interesting. If yes, then you can't go wrong with this game.

The most distinctive thing about it is that there's no money, or cost to anything. Everything is free and you can do whatever you want.
Basically a sandbox with missions that unlock new machines, features, and upgrades.

What we have here is a pared down Factorio.  And if you liked Factorio chances are high that you'll like this too.  Get it on sale though because I wouldn't pay more than $5 for this very simple version of Factorio unless you really need to get stuff on conveyor belts.  Building is simpler and moving from place to place too, quickly you'll unlock things you might be familiar with like underground belts as well as unfamiliar bits like cutting, rotating, cutting again, painting, and finally mashing it all together in the correct order to make the HUB's required design to move-on.  After you beat a level you aren't whisked away to a clean slate with a new requirement.  No, instead you wallow in your own factory of filth and need to continue sending those previously crafted shapes to upgrade your factory.  Things get tangled up and space becomes crowded.  You encumber yourself with your early factories so its really all your fault.  But you can destroy faster than you can build here so no matter.

One lil thing that I really don't like is that the hot bar at the bottom with all your construction supplies doesn't have enough options.  For example the splitter and the joiner are on the same button meaning you first have to cycle through after selecting to get the correct joiner with teh inputs on the correct sides.  Its a little problem but annoying enough that I hafta tell you about it because you are gonna use the splitter and the joiner quite a lot in this game and more so than everything else except conveyor belts.  Another item that takes a second to get used to is how paint combines to make other colors: yellow is made by combining GREEN and RED.  WHAT?!>!

For work and school I build data processing pipelines then I go back home to build shape processing pipelines.
Quite relaxing logistics puzzle game.

I enjoy this style of factory building: top down design and no useless avatar. It allows you to focus on the design rather than the construction.

The levels progressed really naturally, introducing new mechanics and teaching you how to use them. Only levels 20 and 26 required some non-intuitive stacking patterns that the game would be better without.

I liked that the upgrade system overlapped with the level objectives, but was disappointed that it stalled after tier 7 where everything started to require more of the same components rather than a variety, and the upgrade rewards became insubstantial. Worse, those shapes were the most awkward ones from levels 20 and 26, making their production hard to scale.

The level rewards got strange after level 20, unlocking a bunch of electrical components that you didn't need to progress through L26. It seems like they tried to transition you to a different kind of game play (flexible factories) without the natural progression from earlier in the game. I completed L26 and unlocked free play, but still had no idea how to use the electrical components to build this new kind of factory. I think the game needs several more structured levels to get you over this learning hurdle.

~~~ Update ~~~

After a break I went back to this to try creating the build-anything factory. It ended up being a ton of fun. With modest initial goals I was able to prototype a general purpose factory, and then slowly scale it up, work out the kinks, etc.  Eventually I made a second and third copy of the factory that pushed me up to level 234. In theory this keeps scaling until you run out of hub delivery slots (16) which should be enough to put you over level 1000, but there's not much point in actually building that.
very fun but you need to have a desire to make things efficient to truly enjoy this game

Shapez.io is most likely the best Factory-Builder ever, in that it is different in all aspects, from game play to art style.

Pros:
When I think of simplifying the genre, I always come back to the core concepts of Shapez.io, it's simplicity in style and in function. It's emphasis on ratios, how many items per second the machine can handle in relation to others, encourages large scale factories and production of something as a full flowing belt.

The game features no cost to place buildings, which also encourages large factories. But to use the copy-and-paste features you need the blueprint shape. I ended up building a giant factory that produces 12 belts of blueprint shape by hand to make the later game easier.

You are encouraged to keep old factories, so you end up with a mess of spaghetti belts and chaos if you don't organise things. This can look really cool.

THE GAME IS LIKE $5 AND IT GOES ON SALE ALL THE TIME! You can play it online for free but you don't need to!

Cons:
Shapez.io used to have almost two endings. There was beating the premade levels and fully upgrading everything, and then there was making a make-anything machine. This took a while, and a lot of logistic work. But with the addition of the wires update, once you were done the game would automatically progress. No interaction. BUT THEN an update came out that made it so later levels progressed based off item throughput, and made upgrades infinite. This ruined the second ending. You now had to do the bare minimum of setting the upgrade shapes and pressing upgrade to progress. It's tedious and stupid. It isn't fun.

The music can get a bit annoying. It's good, but annoying.

Stacked miners should be something you get from square one.

Honestly, 4.5 stars. While I love Factorio and more traditional Factory-Builders, Shapez.io is my pick for it's simplicity and enjoyable experience.

This game was supposed to be a small, simple game to pass the time. I've already found myself going to bed late because of these stupid, STUPID machines I have to build. I tell myself I won't do it, I won't get pulled in - but no, the depot desperately needs a complex AF shape and I am taking it as an insult to my intelligence if I give up!!

10/10, pick it up if it's on sale!

I want to like this. I really do. It reminds me fondly of a game I played as a child, because of the simple graphics and the idea behind the gameplay.

But then I started playing it. And quickly I realized that the gameplay is a mess. The idea of the base shapes and colours being locked in place means you quickly end up making a big mess of your machines, constantly having to change them to work in the new parts and new goals.

Then you come across the level where you have to build a blue shape, but there's no blue colour in sight. And as it turns out, you have to zoom out to find a blob of blues far away, something the game doesn't tell you, so now you have to build very long conveyor belts between parts of the ridiculously big map.

Others have compared it to Factorio. I have never played that game, its graphics do not appeal to me, so I don't know if the comparison is accurate. But many of those reviews mention it having a sandbox mode. And that is what this game desperately need to be any good. I came into this game wanting to be creative and make all kinds of shapes from base shapes and colours, not having to micromanage everything because of locked in shapes and colours.

Why this game has so many positive reviews is beyond me, but at this point in time I cannot recommend that anyone buys it, it's just too unfinished gameplay wise.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This is an amazing automation game! You extract and process shapes to deliver to your hub as the goal shapes get increasingly complex as you unlock new machines to make them. At first it seems like simple cutting and extracting, but soon you will be painting the pinwheel white then cutting it into quarters then fusing three of those quarters back together then painting the other quarter blue then stacking that quarter on top of a semicircle... yeah, shapes can get real complex. There is also some tricky parts, such as Level 20 where you have to make sure one of the quadrants is smaller than the other three (there's no scaler) which requires some hard thinking and work. You can also upgrade your machines to go faster until your conveyor belt becomes a Formula 1 racecar. Buy now, it's totally worth it!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is an exceptional game at the most reasonable price. I am the type to buy a game, play it for 30 minutes to an hour and never look at it again. It's a problem. I clocked almost 12 hours in one day and I feel I have received more enjoyment/entertainment out of this few dollar game than I have AAA new releases. 

This game really pushes you forward, without being over-bearing. The concept I find wildly amazing is the fact that the devs ENCOURAGE mistakes. Most games often punish you for making a goof-up. This game has no currency (except blueprint shapes to copy and paste HUGE machines.) This essentially means the only investment you have put forward is time and brain power. But the more the game continues, the more you build very optimized, successful machines. The map is never ending, so if you want to keep a junk-pile for inspiration, just keep it!

Soundtrack is amazing!! I can play for 12 hours in one day and bob my head along the WHOLE time. Absolutely perfect job catching your intended vibe. 

Brain power. This game will exercise your mind, if you let it. I am on break from school, and I usually find the idle mind syndrome a bit overwhelming. This game is a perfect remedy to keep your mind active in a light, casual STRESS FREE zone. I can't stress that enough, this game is absolutely relaxing. It allows you to sit back and watch your contraption for a minute. Judge its progress and determine where needs to be optimized (you can always get better lol.) 

I have played this genre before, but have never tried factorio. This game has made me wish list it for my summer break (when I have more time to play.) If I had to guess, this is more of a logistic puzzle game to chill out to without stress, where factorio is more involved. Nothing wrong with that, but I have a feeling this will be more played.

TL;DR - Dieses Spiel ist SEHR GUT! KAUFEN ES JETZT :)

This game is pretty cool. I think it gets too crazy too fast. After about 6 hours my brain just kinda looked at the amalgamation of machinery and shapes that I had created, and decided it was too much for me to handle.

One thing I wish I had been told is that you should be really mindful of how you use your space around the hub area. Part of me is too lazy to redesign the space around it and it seems like a daunting task to finally organize everything.

One small complaint I have is the fact that you slowly unlock each machine part. It means that as you progress, you have to keep redesigning your previous builds to be better and faster. That's probably a good thing to some, but I personally find it kind of annoying to spend so much time on something only to find a better way an hour later.

This review is mostly small complaints or whatever but I do recommend this game, especially if you really like puzzling logic games.

For those playing factorio and thinking "oh ...  this looks like factorio". Stop. 

Despite what you may think, this is not like factorio in many ways.
Factorio is a sandbox of creativity. If you like creativity, you'll will barely find it here. The game is pretty linear and has pretty clear objectives.

shapezio, is a puzzle game, with levels that you progress each time you solve a puzzle. Not a creative sandbox. Nothing like factorio for some of us that don't like this style of puzzles. 

You solve a puzzle, you're done with this factory, go to the next one and make an entirely new setup from scratch. 

What if I just want to relax, and drive a vehicle, kill some creeps, deal with an easy task, improve a bottleneck just because I want to, not because a puzzle forces me to? And that's my point! This is not factorio, it's a puzzle game. Do not play this game with the wrong expectations. You might love this game, or if you come with the wrong expectations, you might just ignore it and hate that you spend 6 dollars for something you realized you're not interested in.

I'm not recommending this game, because I came with the wrong expectations because of some reviews. The game might be good for other people, but I expected something different so unfortunately I did not enjoy it. The fact that I had to rebuilt the factory over and over, and solve very specific puzzles instead of relaxing and do whatever I wanna do like I do in factorio, threw me off. Do not listen to the reviews that talk about factorio, they'll make you not enjoy this game for what it is.

Shapez.io is essentially a minimalist Factorio.

If you’ve never played Factorio or a more complex factory game, and found the genre a bit daunting then Shapez.io is the perfect place to start! If, like me, have experience with the genre then you should still have an enjoyable experience.

I like the progression in this game a lot. Each mechanic unlocks as you progress through the levels, gradually teaching you all the different elements. Eventually you run out of unlocks and move onto freeplay. The ultimate goal is to make a “Make Anything Machine”, that will automatically make whatever shape freeplay throws at you (and the shapes do get harder in freeplay as well, so there’s even more progression past this point).

The game is not very well optimised - not surprising, considering it was written in javascript. This kind of game REALLY needs proper optimisation. Factorio can handle way bigger and complex without as much as a hiccup (*cough* C++ *cough*). Even though the game lags it wasn’t so bad as to be unplayable.

I recommend you pick up Shapez.io and discover the joy of automation!

This game makes me feel smart when I play it.  More tools are unlocked as different shapes are delivered, and you're continuously finding improved ways of building complex things.  The copy / paste feature is a gamechanger.  I'm able to create my own modules to process shapes in new ways (eg. I created a diagonal-cutter; it takes a block, and 'cuts' it into 2 diagonal parts), AND I can reuse this module as many times as I want.  I'm excited to try to build a computer inside this game!  It's definitely possible.

Before I get to the reasons I can't recommend this game, I want to first sing its praises. It's a very enjoyable and well-made game. The big issue is this game, while not actively predatory (e.g. no microtransactions) it is addictive. Like not in the "oh I had so much fun I didn't want to put it down" colloquial way, but in the people who are susceptible to getting addicted to substances might have trouble kind of way. I don't remember the exact circumstances, but I very much struggled to shut this game down, even after playing well past my normal limits. Again, I want to emphasize that this isn't because of anything malicious done by the developers, but the psychological hooks are still there. If one wanted to reduce this issue, I would recommend putting in more stopping points and even reminders to take a break from playing. I know it's not an issue for everyone, but it is for me, and I can't recommend the game if I can't let myself play it again, even though I really want to.

It's like a super-streamlined version of Factorio. It simplifies away many constraints (power, enemies, building costs, research) but retains the same open-ended depth of factory design possibilities, which is the entire focus of the game.

While not as graphically appealing as Factorio or Satisfactory, this simple but complex game is a great addition to the automation genre. Simple graphics fit the theme of the game. An infinite map to create massive structures with no limits. 
Combining shapes sounds easy, and it is -- at first. "But you have an infinite map," you might say. [strike]Spaghetti is not progress[/strike] Trying to make the most compact and efficient machines is one of the main aspects of the game, as you do not have to manage resources [spoiler](besides a shape allowing you to copy and paste areas)[/spoiler] like in other games in the genre. It gets big. Fast. If you do not organize things in the beginning, you will have to restructure or fix your spaghetti later. 
This game is great for people that love min/maxxing their factories and that love finding the best solution to a problem. 

+ 1 for simple gameplay that can be used in complex ways
+ 1 for making an interesting twist on the normal automation genre

Really good game, right up to the point where you create a make-anything-machine. The performance is degraded to the point where the game is nearly unplayable, even on an optimized make-anything-machine. Running this game on an i9 / RTX 3070, my computer should have no problem handling the game. Not only does the game become quite unplayable, it mis-counts the number of pieces being returned to the center because of the performance, so it can take multiple attempts at different tick rates to achieve a level completion.

I recommend the game as it really is a good game, but the later levels are simply not fun due to the performance degradation. Posting a bug report regarding this issue on the github for the game, the creator responded saying there really isn't anything he can do about it. Take note.

If you've played and enjoyed Factorio and want something else to scratch the itch, this is really worth taking a look. I put it off for a while because of the simplistic graphics, but the gameplay is really good and it's easy to get sucked in. The gameplay revolves around 'mining' shapes and colours, mixing paint, cutting shapes, and feeding them along belts in increasingly challenging configurations.

[b]Differences to Factorio[/b]
- There are no power (or monster) concerns - build as many of anything as you like
- Blueprints cost shapes to place
- There are no 'grabbers', so you can't pull items off belts, you have to split everything
- Belts only have one item instead of 2 lanes
- You can't do a "main bus" because you need different shapes for everything

[b]Pros[/b]
- Good background music
- Runs well
- Distils the Factorio experience to simple shapes
- Research tree
Factorio but geometry. Absolutely incredible content, and so worth the price.

If you've wanted to get started in games like factorio or satisfactory, but feel overwhelmed by the massive scale of the content and the mods and everything, this is a great place to get started. It's simple at times, and frustrating at others. It's a game that, even after you reach level 26 and have everything unlocked, you still want to keep playing. Even once you have a MAM, or a Make Everything machine, you still want to keep going and keep constructing. A diamond in the rough to be sure! This amazing game got me into factory games which are now a staple for me. 

The price is great and worth at least twice as much. Knowing what I know now I'd pay upwards of 30 or 40 dollars for this game. 

The music is actually lowkey tremendous and I look forward to hearing it every time I boot the game up. 

The graphics and UI are SO crisp and clean. It's simple, very effective, and easy to look at. Not overtly complex graphics but the style is perfectly crafted and it feels amazing. 

The game play is very zen and enjoyable. There's nothing to pressure you and you can't fail, it's all forward progress. It starts simple and slowly gains in complexity with some real brain teasers along the way. The first thing it wants you to do is use conveyor belts to bring basic circles to the main hub. By level 18 you're figuring out how to stack shapes onto ghost layers and maximizing throughput on your blueprint shape for mega factory copy pasting. WAIT WHAT? It's awesome

WIRES UPDATE?!?! This was a HUGE addition to the game and an absolutely incredible one at that. It's completely not necessary to beat or enjoy the game, but if you are into programming or want to experiment with logic gates, this is a great game in which to do it. I played an alpha version not connected to steam before the wires officially came out. It was a blast! So I actually have about 40 or 50 more hours than what my account suggests. 

You should definitely check out this game for it's amazing content at a ridiculously good price! The dev has even more planned additions to the game in the future like a puzzle dlc which I'm really excited about! 

I was really lucky to stumble across this game, do yourself a favor and check it out! There's a free demo available as well!

First I'll say I've played this about 8 hours a day since I installed it...and had a few long nights beyond that...really great puzzle game.  I will say that most of these reviews are misleading though...this is NOT factorio, satisfactory, etc...and CANNOT even be compared to it. 
There's really 2 phases to this game...the first 26 levels, are puzzles...that's it.  You can check out shapez.io for the free in-browser demo...run through some puzzles, see if you like it.  You're NOT building a mega factory, there's no rockets to launch, you're not getting off any planets, etc....you're solving puzzles.  Logically: 99% are simple, however it'll take you hours (overall) to actually design the "factory" (I use the term loosely) and optimize it.  If that doesn't sound fun, then you probably won't like this game.
After level 26 you're in "free play" mode and the shapes you need to craft factories for are just randomly jumbled mess.  Well, obviously making/destroying factories for quick puzzles is lame...BUT...because of the fairly robust logic/wire system in this game, the end-game goal is actually to make a "machine" that can analyze and actually create the required shapes automatically.  Sounds insane when you first start playing, but yes it's possible...and super fun.
If anything I wrote sounds appealing, you'll love this game.  I've gotten probably 100 hours with it already...hard to argue with a $6.99 price on that!

First of all, the game itself is great, but I will give a thumb down because of one terrible design flaw which will ruin the whole game.
So before I say something good about the game I want to say the following:
The game has a awful savegame design. I played for 8 hours and everything went fine but then the game crashed during a save. And that's it, everything is gone. If your game or PC crashes while the game saves, it will delete your entire progress and that's my problem.
A savefile should always be kept until the next save progress is fully done. Or just keep always 2 save files. This way you can always go back to the last autosave instead of loosing everything if one file get corrupted.

And now to the good point of the game.
I didn't wanted to play it again after I lost everything. What would be the point of playing a game, where I can always loose everything down to nothing? Especially for a game like this one. It just didn't made any sense.
But... I couldn't. I had so much fun playing it the first 8 hours, optimizing my whole build make everything better and better and develop flexible systems all over my base. It is so addicting. It is like a factorio simplified down to it's essence and nothing else. Relaxed and challenging in some weird way. I am sure that my review will not always be negative. The day will come where I will give it a thumbs up. I'm even glad that I didn't bought it in the sale, but paid the full price.

There's little in the way of advanced strats (at least for now, though there are a few puzzly aspects later on), but that's fine, especially if you're learning how to manage conveyor belts for the first time. Lots of stuff you do in this game carries over to other logistics titles, like making conveyor buses, load balancing, manifold setups, expandable/reusable design, etc..

Great place to try entering the logistics scene before going for Mindustry, Satisfactory, Factorio, or others, or for logistics veterans that just want a place to relax and watch that factory grow. And if you just want to see what it's all about you can just play the demo.

shapez.io is basically factorio simplified and abstracted. You build machines to extract shapes, put them on conveyor belts, cut them, paint them, combine them, and then deposit them into your central hub. There are no resources, you can build anything you want, when you want, it just costs time. You gather shapes to unlock more machines and make them go faster.

I think shapez.io is a great idea, and for the price, a great game too. It is very simple to understand and get into, and very easy to lose time with too. The only real problem I had was that after a while your map gets very cluttered with old production lines you made that get in the way. Yes you can delete them and make them better, but it always sucks a little to erase a bunch of progress. I wish that a game could be spread out over multiple maps perhaps, or have some sort of reason to reset everything. As of right now, I had a lot of fun, but don't really want to return to my cluttered map or start over with the same goals.

Despite the small gripe of the building clutter, the game is a lot of fun and definitely worth checking out.

Shapez.io is a refreshing take on the classic factory planner genre. You develop across an infinitely-expanding plane dotted with deposits of different shapes and colors. What I like about this game the most is the relaxing, no-pressure atmosphere it has. This is not a management game. There are no construction costs, no time constraints, and no hostile creatures to disrupt your supply lines. The absence of any sort of time constraints, such as having to meet a quota within a certain amount of time, means that one can develop their infinite shape-making factory at their own pace. Shapez.io is an excellent product so far and completely worth its base price.

The quintessence of the genre.  There's no framework, no story here -- you are building purely and simply because you can.  Resources aren't limited, nothing's going to break or attack you, there's no research tree separate from the primary gameplay.

It's as pure as Pong, but with conveyor belts.  If Conway's old Game Of Life was created by the djinn from Tim Powers' novel DECLARE, this would be that game.

And it's like $7. What are you waiting for?

Got this game on sale, and very happy I did. This is a great game for anyone who appreciates efficient problem solving. I'm an engineer myself, and have poured hours into shapez.io.

At its most basic, this game is about manipulating shapes and colours to deliver a requested combination of the two categories. While a few of the shapes are surprisingly tough to crack, solving the combination method isn't really the ultimate goal. 

What makes this game so engaging is that you can use a series of operations and circuit logic to make smarter, more efficient "machines" to produce the requested shapes. The real point is to create the fastest machines you can without wasting space or materials. You'll want to find ways to make your machines easy to re-use with the copy-paste tool, as well, as you'll be needing them multiple times. 

After unlocking Free Play at level 26, you will have all the tools you need to make a fully automated factory. But that's really just the beginning, as you build and improve upon your Make Anything Machine (MAM). Soon, the level requirements shift from demanding a certain number of a shape, to needing a shape delivered at a given minimum rate. Can you create a MAM that produces shapes quickly enough? That's the end goal of the game. Though I personally think you'll get more out of the solution if you work to make a MAM that is also easy to build and pleasing to look at.

Factorio has two sides of gameplay. They are:
- The factory must grow
- Clever and efficient designing

shapez.io embodies "The factory must grow" which I'm sure will be good for most players. You will spend your time getting larger and larger. The gameplay loop is obvious and addictive.

shapez.io chooses to drop "Clever and efficient designing". It doesn't take very long before the "best ways to do everything" become apparent. There's no puzzle game aspect here. The map is infinite in size and the game is not punishing. There's exactly one way to do everything. The result is that my game will match up to your game nearly one-to-one, just change the locations of stuff. 

For the above reason, I wasn't very into shapez.io and didn't play for too long. Still, I feel like I got my money's worth and I think many will agree. For that reason I do recommend, but be aware of what type of experience you are looking for.

For extra praise:
- Man, the music is just banging. Music easily kept me playing and having a good time.
- This game is unnecessarily attractive. Makes the price tag feel low.
- The UI is minimalist, sleek, easy to use. shapez is ahead on how a factory builder should incorporate ease-of-use.
- Very late into the game, "wires" are unlocked. These are a bit more "puzzle game". Just introduced too late imo. 

For minor nit-picks:
- Copy-paste has become a standard of the genre and this game has it - unlocked after level 12, quite far into the game. Even worse, it costs resources to use in a game about everything being free. The inclusion feels confused. Copy-paste should be introduced very early and cost nothing to use. Knowing what to do, but having to painstakingly build the exact same thing more than once is just tedious. Skipping this process is not robbing anybody of any experience.

Incredibly addictive. Am pleasantly surprised. After having played Factorio and Satisfactory thought the automation genre was at it's peak. shapez.io shows that it still has new ways to express itself in an entertaining way. As with all automation games, the game starts of simple but becomes increasingly more difficult as the game progresses. Have just scratched the surface. 

The game isn't penalizing you for placing buildings as these are free. The only thing the game is restricting is the number of inputs to the main Hub. To this hub you will bring all sorts of shapes that you will have to create through automation. Having your buildings go faster means bringing a specific shape to the main hub. Every shape is build of max 4 blocks with an additional 8 colors the shape can be in. This give a lot of different combinations that the game may ask for to be build. The next step is adding shapes on top of each other to create even more complex shapes. Not sure what is beyond that but am afraid to ask.

For the price of the game it's a must buy for anyone enjoying automation games. It's just to good to not have played.
I enjoy trying to find the most effective method. It's fun.

The pieces you make to complete a quest are from you...you made that piece.  It is similar but for some reason in my oldish age, its amazing. it is really a lot of fun.  It starts out meh but damn soon you are trying to find shapes to cut up and rotate pieces to make other shapes to complete quests and damn thats fun.   I can watch a show and play this and it gets harder and harder as time goes by. Like starting out you are gathering simple pieces and putting them in the hub to check off an achievement and now 8 hours in I am gathering shapes, slicing them in 1/4, each 1/4 gets rotated, then colored then rotated again, then joined with another shape, and then another and then another and another and another....all these pieces being rotates, colored, rotated, and whatnot to make a cool looking shape that is put into the hub to achieve a goal and damn now its 8 hours in and you are solving math problems you never thought you would be solving.  Brilliant game. well worth $20 and i bought it for $4.  if anyone is reading, hit me up. i have bought 2 copies of the game.  ill buy at least 4 more bc of how much time i have put into it. Very simple game. Basically 2 different types of resources, Shapes and Colours. Starts simple, either a certain amount of 1 shape, or a combination of 1 Shape and Colour. You get to cut it into halves soon, and rotate them. Next, you get to combine different halves together to get a mis-mash of shapes. Then you end up requiring 4 different quarters of shapes together, each with their own colour.

Does that seem very hard? It's just from 2 different types of resources. Just Shapes, and Colours. And you get this beautifully, wonderful game. Of course, like other games of the kind, you need to optimize your factories to get the best results. Haven't even mentioned the layering of shapes. Previously, you had to come up with the layers yourself, but now they provide a hint on making them.

Played 40+ hours on it back when it was fairly new. Now, with all the upgrades and improvements, I'm enjoying it very much. Very good buy for such a well made game. Plenty of guides online to help improve gameplay as well.
