A simple yet really fun factory game.
In the game there are 4 basic shapes, and each shape can be chopped up in to 4 quadrants and recombined with other quadrants. You can stack shapes on shapes creating a stack of up to 4 shapes.
And you can paint shapes or parts of them 7 colours (3 basic colours, plus the combinations).
You can rotate the shapes.
The game slowly unlocks all this in a very logical way, asking you to send specific combinations to the central hub to unlock the next feature.
You move shapes around using conveyor belts.
After 26 different shapes have been provided, you have unlocked all the features and you get advanced tools to do sorting and even make a factory to auto build the shapes being requested. At which point you are optimising your factory to build it ever more efficient.
By the time I got to a point where I was happy with my factory, I had invested almost 70 hours in to the game, and I enjoyed every minute.
If you enjoy games like Factorio, I recommend giving this a go. You can try the game on the website first.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
If you like building factories (i.e. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/427520/Factorio/]Factorio[/url]), you will probably like this game too. You can also [url=shapez.io]try[/url] it first.

[h1]Longer version:[/h1]
This game (as the name implies) is all about shapes. The shape is made up of four corners, every corner can be colored. You can even leave them out. You can also stack the different shapes together to create more complex looking shapes.

In the game the so called "hub" will ask you to create and deliver a certain amount shapes. After delivering them you will unlock new buildings, which introduce new mechanics and makes the progression faster. At the same time though, the shapes will get more complex (multiple colors, shapes, etc.). You will also unlock speed upgrades for the buildings in the game.

So if this speaks to you, you will (probably) enjoy it

Last but not least, this game is also open-source!

Absolutely fantastic idea. It's really the resource/belt/machine/ratio mechanics boiled down to the simplest possible form of geometric shapes. Think Factorio minus graphics and combat with colors and shapes in place of resources with unlimited resource nodes and no electricity.

In absence of story or overarching goal the challenge here is managing growing scale by continuous refactoring and standardizing existing hubs. The game does and excellent job by giving you smaller objectives (literally just shows you shapes you need to assemble) early on as it familiarizes you, in pace I find perfect, with progressively complex machines and additional, space-efficient, versions of existing ones.On top of this you have semi-optional goals granting you speed upgrades to entire "classes" of your machines, e.g. cutting/rotation/stacking, painting/mixing colors, belt speed, node extraction.

I can see how some people would be turned away by the simplistic visuals but to me this is part of the challenge. At a certain scale, when everything starts blurring together, you need to up your space-planning and standardization game, with blueprints unlocked to help you with that (copy/pasting costs some accumulated shapes!). In the late-game wires and simple, programmable logic kicks in to let you automate entire sections of your factory, down to automatically picking and producing the shapes you need.

Game is being actively expanded (wires being a late 2020 addition) and on top of it all game's source-code is mostly open-source which further ups the chance of future additions even if the original developer takes a back seat.

[h1]TL;DR: You will lose weeks to this game.[/h1]

If you know me, you know I only buy things on sale. We're talking like a [i]minimum[/i] of 50% off. But, seeing as this game has a free demo website, I started with that.

Today, I purchased this game for full price. A whopping five dollars. To you, not that big of a deal. To me, it's only the fifth or sixth game I have purchased full price. This game deserves $10 of the $5 I spent, even though that doesn't make any sense...

I have spent many hours of many days slowly filling the map with crazy machines. You don't necessarily [i]need[/i] everything I have made, but I certainly have made them.

[b]Seriously: set timers.[/b] If you need to do something later, you had better give yourself time. Hours will disappear. Be prepared. You think I'm kidding, don't you? I'm not. This game will eat your day.

Now buy this game. [b]11/10[/b]

Shapez.io does nothing groundbreaking. But it is still strangely satisfying.
There is no dangers, no time limits or anything else of the ilk. 

Instead the game simply asks you to create simple objects of increasing complexity. Whether you want to go with minimum effort slow production, or try to create the most lean efficient machine ever is entirely up to you.

While there are the "main" objectives, keep in mind you will still need to make more of the previously created shapes and maybe some other similar shapes to improve the efficiency of already unlocked technologies.

In all, don't expect the game to blow your mind if you have played any other factory games. What it does is deliver a clean looking puzzle for you to just fiddle around with in your own pace. Just be aware that time might disappear quickly if you do.

Also, thank you for having the in-browser demo at shapez.io, which got me hooked.

Pure logistics gameplay, if you like managing pipelines, conveyor belts ect in base builder games you are going to love this game.

The endgame logic system is a big jump in skill but opens up near infinite solutions. Early game is satisfying creating your own blueprints for optimised ratios and footprint. Even if you never reach the endgame it’s well worth picking up.

Shapez.io is clearly inspired by Factorio. It feels very similar to the belt mechanics from that game, but adds/changes enough that it becomes it's own thing.  You modify shapes  one operation at a time (cut/color/stack/etc) to create increasingly complex shapes and feed them to the hub.  It's a chill little game you can play at your own pace.  The fun comes from creating a design, watching the pieces flow through all of it, and ending up with something that looks far more complex than the sum of it's parts.  


Certainly worth the $5 asking price, especially if you're looking for a relaxed puzzle experience with an increasing sense of scale.

I tend to measure games on a hour per £ ratio. 1-1 is an acceptable ratio for me. This has a 6-1 ratio so far. Great value.

Pros - 
Fun and diverse soundtrack that didn't get old in the 30+ hours I played.
Sleek, clear and good looking visuals.
Engaging, complex gameplay that builds and iterates on itself.

Cons -
A couple of QOL things missing. Auto-tunnel would be great, for instance, as would the ability to build from the zoomed out overview.
Can get a bit jankey and framey towards the later game
The editing mode is a tiny bit too zoomed in for me, but that's likely a performance conceit.

As a game for £5, can't go wrong. Try it out!

I like this game because the puzzles are good.  The challenge of making a "make anything" machine is also excellent.

If you're an engineer by trade, you might lose your job snorting the fresh powder that is this game instead.

Make some shapes. No rush yet? Just wait. Use your skills. You know you're better than this. You know how to make GOOD machines. There... that's better. Hmm... running slow... must make more...
Oh... that piece would have come in handy. Oh well, I'll just make my new machines using that. If only I could make PARALLEL machines...

...but you don't have that copy-paste item yet. Patience. It's what got you this far into your career. THERE. Oh what sweet dopamine that is! Now you have currency to spend on expanding your beautifully crafted parallel machines. Now you feel it. If only just one more level. Oh... GODDAMMITT!!

Know what?  If this is what I have to work with... these are the tools I can expect later on... I'm going to throw everything away and start from scratch because I.am.SO.much.better.than.this.

Then you start over.
Then your machines are beautiful and parallel.
Then the rush comes in.
Then the sweet dopamine and serotonin get you high.
Then the responsibilities in the real world can wait... because you keep playing... because it's sooooo gooooood...

Then you begin to shiver from the serotonin syndrome.
Then you question if you should keep going.
Then you realize your daily responsibilities are being neglected.
Then you see that at some stage it's the 'end'... you will get to "Freeplay"... the "End" of the game.
Then you will quit... you promise yourself.

Then you get to "FreePlay"
Then the floodgates open.

What you once thought would be the stage that lets you quit this drug and go back to the real world... will, instead, get you bit by the Everything Machine.
Just build it.
You know you want to.
Tweak it when it fails a level here or there. Build a gated storage tank to pump shapes into the hub at a faster rate. Build an automated timer to do the work for you. Build a way to adjust the timer automatically. Enhance. Repeat.

Your job, s.o., chores, pets... kids...
You'd better learn how to pace yourself in this game or they ALL go away.

Okay, if you like simulation games then you will be glued to this one. 

Imagine Factorio without having to worry about threats or having to manually build items before you can automate them and then build with those items. In this game you just build. This is an ultimate sandbox title where only your imagination and designs are the limit here! 

The game is simple. You mine for shapes which you can cut up and re-arrange into a different shape along with different colours. Colours are also something that you can mine but with colours you can also combine them to make new colours to use.

This game presents you with constraints such as needing to scale up production of making these different shapes so you can make them fast enough to achieve your production goal. Of course you could just leave the game running all day but it's encouraged that you do it quicker as the amount of shapes you need to produce increases which means you're going to be forced to have to scale up eventually. Some shapes also require you to make a certain amount each second.

However, this game makes it insanely easy to scale up. You can copy, paste, cut and then rotate a pattern that was derived from what you've made before. There's no cost other than time.

The graphics in this game are also rather simple but they are simple in such a way that is pleasing to the eye. 

I am satisfied with this game. However, if you're a hard core Factorio player then you may find this game to be overly simplistic but in my opinion I think this game is a wonderful introduction for a beginner to learn how to scale and produce things for a simulation title.

I would highly recommend giving this game a go! It's very cheap and has a lot of replay value.

Would I recommend it? yes.
This game is like factorio stripped down to its bare bones, there are no resources, it's all infinite, no enemies, no terrains, and the graphics are quite minimum. Your objective is to construct shapes out of other shapes and colours. This may be one of the simplest games I've ever played and yet I still found it endearing. Making shapes out of other shapes was interesting to figure out and the milestones were always satisfying. Paired with a nice soundtrack this games is quite fun.
But it isn't perfect, once i got up to tier 17 the game got too laggy for the game to run smoothly and building became almost painful. Looking for certain shapes was tedious and annoying. After a while building became the same and was quite monotonous.
For a game that is in early access i'll let a lot of these slide but the developers need to optimize the game for a playable experience and different buildings and/or something that breaks up the same copy paste construction line should be implemented and some way to make the area interesting would also be nice.
Overall a 6/10; worth the money but has some holes in it

Have you ever been cutting wrapping paper for a gift, and the scissors start to glide?     That's what this whole game FEELS like.

The interface has fading transitions and glides around like ice. The construction of conveyors is smooth, and the game's software knows where you're going before you finish. There are many indie games out there who suffer from general clunkiness, bad interfaces, and other nags. shapez.io is not one of those. All the parts click in a satisfying way.

A++ Factorio lite(I personally have over 6000 hours in Factorio), but still complex in its own unique style. I was initially frustrated with the copy tool being locked away but am growing to understand. Would recommend this to anyone even slightly interested in factory builder games given the price. 

My recommendation to anyone who gets frustrated early, is to build it spaced out, so you get a feel of the belts and such, then figure out how to remake it to save the most space. There are no baddies to shoot, the resources seem to be infinite, and the music is chill. The only enemy in this game is your own impatience. Use the game to train that impatience out of yourself by slowing down, zooming out, and thinking about it just a little longer. Sometimes the best way to get from point A to point B is not a straight line.

Shapez is a very casual and relaxing factory building game. It gives you the basic building blocks with which to do so in the initial stages to then allow you to build increasingly complex production lines to deliver them to your core and make the process faster. 
There's no outside pressure to do it quickly, there's no cost for any building blocks (only if you wish to copy-paste them for speed), so together with its relaxing music, it's a pretty enjoyable relaxed experience.

So...I'm kinda torn on this game.

Initially, I love it.  I enjoy the concept, and the leveling is fun and somewhat intuitive (for the most part...we'll get back to that).  Taking just 4 shapes and cutting them into quadrants, coloring, cutting and combining them into the required shapes is actually fun.  So is developing your own little 'factories' for each operation you can eventually copy and paste around the board...then upgrade, and move on.

But there is a bad.  And it's hard to describe without actually playing the game.  Eventually, there seems to be a large dependence on a piece type that's not actually supported by the games own systems.  You need to combine 'shrunken' pieces to make the shapes.  But the game doesn't actually support shrunken pieces.  Every other type of combination can be made separately and combined later, even 4 separate quadrant pieces.  But not shrunken ones.  They force you to create these frankensteiniean, ugly pieces and go through some odd cut and combine process to keep the game from restoring it back to the correct size.

This is exasperated by the level that is supposed to teach you this technique.  The instructional bit says to seperate the pieces out, and recombine them...but you can't.  It's own instructions can't show how to make it work.

Now this wouldn't be a problem to me, but the later levels DEPEND on this.  A LOT.  I got to a level that required a shrunken piece inside another shrunken piece in only one quadrant and I said that's it.  It simply isn't worth the pain to try and not undo the work you've done trying to make these pieces because you can't figure out how to rotate it just the right way.

So while I want to recommend the game, I can't for it being too annoying in the later levels for me to want to continue playing.  Make it so I can shrink a bit and cut it apart WITHOUT it undoing itself, like you would actually think would happen, and I may actually come back to make endless factories of increasing sizes just to fiddle with the game.  But as long as it depends on that mechanic itself doesn't support, I can't recommend this game.

General: 

Rating: E	
Price: $4.99
Genre: Automation
Time played: 17.7 Hours

Ever play Factorio?  Here’s a minimalist version of the game, also there’s no enemies. Just crazy amounts of tracks, machines and shapes. 

Gameplay - 10

The game starts off simple enough, you have to deliver a shape to the main HUB.  Okay simple enough.  Once you reach the required amount you unlock something else.  Now you need to provide a different shape.  Okay still not too hard, each shape builds upon the other ones, unlocking new machines to use in crafting/constructing newer shapes.  Then they add in colors, then mixing colors, then stacking then  then then.

How is such a simple game so good?  I started it up and then 5 hours later was trying to determine the best way to rearrange my various ‘factories’ to make them more efficient and productive.  At one point I had to have a certain shape with colors produced and making 8 of them per second. Simple enough.  Just have to tweak this, and this and build a new production line.  Well now that line isn’t producing enough, let's go back and replace some of it and now we’re up to 2 per second.  Hmm.  That’s not right. 

Seriously how is this game so good? The premise is pretty simple but they way they introduce each thing and build upon your previous knowledge is done very well. Each new machine/improvement adds more and more to the game.  I haven’t even finished everything and my ‘factories’ are ridiculously complex. Yet it’s all one simple thing piled upon another and another. 

Story -  N/A

No story, no bad guys, just infinite building. 

Graphics - 10

Simple, elegant and perfect. 

Controls -10(mouse/keyboard)

Point and click.  Then use the keyboard commands as you get more and more involved and don’t have time to click way over there. Again, super simple yet so powerful. 

Repeatability - ??

This is tricky.  In games like this you’re constantly changing things over and over, or thinking of new ways to make your production better/faster.  Or you just unlocked a new piece of equipment or an updated version of something you already have.  Now you have to redo several pieces of your ‘factory’ to make them run smoother.  

So yeah there’s a ton of repeatability.  I even started over 2 times and now have 3 factories at various stages.   Each one is built differently as you can see my thinking and trying to make things easier for later. 


Music - 10

Background noise. Serene and soothing as you rack your brain trying to build this section perfectly. 

Multiplayer - N/A

There’s not any and that’s a good thing, don’t want some moron messing up my exquisitely crafted factory. 

Initial Thoughts:

Only 5 bucks huh?  Well I’ll give it a shot. 

Hmm. so just move squares over, that seems simple enough. Oh now I unlocked a new machine.  So wait I can.


6 hours later. 

Me muttering to myself about how the damn shapes don’t make any sense and how I need to color the bottom left color white, while the top left corner needs to be magenta and then both pressed onto a solid cyan square, then move that onto a blue star shaped.  Which then needs to be delivered to my Hub at 4 per second. 



Soma Says: 

If you’re a fan of automation then this is a must play.  I don’t often do videos, but I got into a streaming mindset and started my 3rd factory.  Here’s a video of the first 2 hours of playing the 3rd factory.  https://www.twitch.tv/videos/811974618  

I’d like to say I’m a master of the game but I’m not, however it’s still fun to watch, you can see the progression and all that. Try not to be too critical of how I did things, I'm still learning. 


If you enjoyed the review check out my curator page : https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28849369/

This is a great game!  Two thumbs up!  

Now, this is definitely a puzzle game in the vein of games like Factorio where you have to create long complicated conveyor belts to connect various shapes and colors together to create outputs of ever-increasing form.  Unlike other games in this genre, including the previous game made by Tobspr, this is just what it is.  There's no monsters, aliens or zombies at night: you just have to build ever-more-complicated shapes to unlock various upgrades and to win the various levels.  It's very relaxing in a zen sort of way as there's no way to fail: at worst you build a slightly wrong shape and can adjust the various cutting and rotating widgets as necessary. 

Note: I advise looking around the map when you first start.  I spent about a half hour trying to cut squares into diamonds before realizing that those come from a separate quarry and weren't some trick of turning squares 45 degrees.  (There are quarries of circles, squares, and other shapes plus red, yellow and blue colors that need to be mixed to make the rest.) 

Also, the tools are great!  Use them and experiment with them.  They are all useful and necessary especially the one that merges and splits lanes, as there is only one end point, The Hub, and while it has about 16 ports you can connect to, you will have dozens if not hundreds of starting points.   I also enjoyed figuring out how to make green and cyan.  I assume I can also make purple, but I haven't experimented with the paint widget enough.

Infiniminer inspired Minecraft, Minecraft and various other Zachtronics games probably inspired IndustrialCraft, which inspired Factorio (that's official!) which may have inspired Inifinifactory along the way, which, long story short, is all distilled down to its purest form in this game. 

Unlike Infinifactory, there's no angry beep and restart if you make the wrong shape. Unlike Industrialcraft, there's no exploding machines (thanks!), or mobs coming in to wreck your base. Unlike Zachtronics games, there are no histograms to stress over how well you do compared to the world. There's no water to spill over your redstone or other disasters to avoid. This game isn't about frustration, it's focused solely on that hunger for ever increasing efficiency and glorious complexity. Not even a theme to distract you.

But you will feel fairly familiar coming from Factorio. Basically what you got here is a more distilled version of just factory building with no real story and focused only on production lines. It has some unique ways of how you produce the shapes which is quite interesting. There is no enemies or other distractions. And you have some logistic challenges due to your main hub.
Overall a really good factory building game with a unique experience that is not trying to be a "realistic" factory.

This is Baby Factorio.

It essentially boils down the essential elements of factorio to its base elements.  This means that necessarily, its less complicated.  This isnt necessarily a bad thing, but makes it a different experience.  It is in some ways very refreshing to be able to see EXACTLY what is going on at a glance, as there is no power generation, pollution or "smelting" or anything like that.  

Definitely worth it at full price.  Would definitely recommend and already have to several of my friends.  If you like playing this, definitely move onto Factorio as they share a lot of the same experience.

Well... I never thought I'd enjoy a game about creating shapes and transporting them to wherever the heck they go could be this addictive! A friend recommended it to me and I was sceptical at first, but after playing it for eh, well, a few hours(!) I was completely and utterly hooked. It looks and sounds so simple, but the longer you play, the more you realize that the game can get very complex and very challenging quite fast. But the thing is that it doesn't get too complicated, because the tips and help you get along the way make sure that you have the time to work with and understand all the new mechanics and intricacies that the game slowly pushes your way.

And it's strangely relaxing. It doesn't push you towards an endgoal and at times I just look at the wonderful 'machine' I've built and enjoy how efficiently it's doing its job. To see you start with simple shapes, then cut them up, turn them, glue them back, add colors, layer them on top of each other to create all-new shapes that you didn't even realize you could make is just so rewarding.

In short: Play it! Enjoy it! And create those Shapez!

Shapez.io looks simple, yet it is a "production puzzle" where you attempt to build a specific shape by combining other shapes and colors, and then improve throughput by adding parallel production lines. As you "advance" by fulfilling certain objectives (building X number of shapes) you unlock more complicated machines, even more upgrades... as your "manufacturing" spreads across the land... 

The game starts simple: connect a certain "shape" production zone to the "hub". Then you steadily step up in complexity as you need to cut the shapes apart (up to 4 times!), rotate them, color them (and combine colors), and recombine different shapes. You also need to combine multiple "completed" shapes together, each a different color. 

While you have "level" objectives, there are also "upgrade" objectives where building a certain number of shapes (and combinations thereof, like 3000 of shape X, and 5000 of shape Y...) would enable speed upgrades. 

You can simply have patience if you don't want to optimize the production, but the fun is attempting to squeeze in some production optimization with some fancy layout. It's easy to put in ONE paint node, but how would you layout FOUR paint nodes, which requires TWO inputs AND one output each? Can you double that too? 

You get stats for how fast is your production for each shape variation, like you are making shape Z at 2.4 per second. As some of those objectives later requires like 8000 units or even more, it can be a LONG wait if you don't optimize. But it can be done. 

And you slowly gain more and more capabilities as you can go "refit" your old area with the new tools you got... and go further and further from the hub (and add "markers" so you can jump around) as you discover more shapes and so on. 

It's endless, and hard to stop playing. If you like the genre, buy it. It compares to games that costs many times more.

Ever played Mindustry, along with old Factorio or the new Satisfactory?
Take the building elements from these and subtract the action segments, and you get a game that is purely logistic based- hours of fun. 

The game is simple and relaxing, yet makes you think about complex approach to logistic problems. Before you know it, you get acquainted with methods such as concurrent and parallel processing; things that would otherwise sound boring and tiresome. 

Shapez holds your hand gently, teaching you along the way how the core mechanics work, but also lets you think for yourself without breaking a sweat. Of course the aforementioned games also have similar concepts but instead of focusing on either the waves of enemies, or the timer, or the grinding, here you are left with thinking about only efficiency. It is this goal that drives your design, and can turn your entire system into a complex piece of art (just look at the sceenshots! some look like PCB components for microprocessors) or a distorted, mumbled, scattered work of art. Either would do! But you would feel the inclination to go back and constantly fix the previous mistakes in your design. 

In a sense this game is a disguised educational app: a perfect logistics simulator without the fancy gfx or high system requirements. . Not to mention the price is darn cheap too.
So what are you waiting for, if you are into the genre, get it. Support the devs while having a blast with it.

Everything that you love about Factorio with an extra dose of chill.  No managing resources, it's just about the proper supplier to consumer ratios and setting up the most efficient layouts to your factory.  The only issue I have with the game is that it takes a long time to get to the point where you can use blueprints.  There really should be earlier access to the blueprint system, as they'd be useful from basically the first ten minutes.  The most recent update added wiring and logic, expanding control over the fine-tuning of your base to ridiculous degrees and there's more to come (including the blueprint thing mentioned above, the dev announced a blueprint library coming up in a later update.)  All this for less than $5, what's not to love?

TL;DR. Build shapes by cutting, colouring and combining with zero restrictions on how you do this. Build big, build small, build duplicates, build simple, build complicated. The game is criminally cheap. The developer is, as of writing, knocking out updates regularly. You can devote as much or as little attention to the game and still get a lot of enjoyment. One of the best valued buys for me this year.


A casual, stress free automation/factory builder. Sure, it's no Factorio but that is its strength. There is no resource restrictions on factory components, if you want a 100 mile long conveyor you go for it. Likewise you're not limited on space which often, in my experience, can prove frustrating when playing games like Factorio.

The challenge, build different shapes and colour combinations from resources dotted around the map and deliver a specified amount to your hub. There is no end state, you can walk away and leave your machines to it. You can make your production lines as efficient, expansive or compact as you like. This allows you to play the game to your preference rather than through arbitrary limitations of the game design.

As you progress through level objectives and targets (reach a certain number of a specific shape and colour combo) you can upgrade equipment and unlock new factory components. These range from faster operational effectiveness of your components to new components that provide extra functionality. The choice is then yours as to whether you want to use these to improve your solutions.

Shapez.io is best explained as Factorio without resource management (atleast, not in the sense of resources that can be depleted), its a game about building a factory that uses recurring shapes to make more intricate shapes that you use for upgrades, and these upgrades then in turn give you access to more elaborate things as well as increase the speed of your machines to make things more intricate in efficient.

In a way, Shapes.io is the embodiment of efficiency and speed, and that's the whole point of the game. Other than "currency tokens" that you start making early on, there are no concrete resources in the game that you need to micromanage. You can build as complex of a system as you want since there's no material requirements for the construction of items, which adds an air to creativity because you feel you aren't constrained to not go "all out." The sole goal is to keep expanding, upgrading, and leveling up. Its an endless gameplay loop, that although might sound boring, never really did for me. Its a very calm and relaxing game to play, and if you're a fan of games like Factorio I highly recommend you try this game. It is well worth the $5 asking price if you enjoy these types of games.

  Shapez.io is very much a problem solving game about solving the flow of production and doing the right action at the right time and optimizing as needed .  It is quite fun creating designs then trying to redo them but more efficiently.
 
 I find Shapez.io relaxing to play, a kind of palate cleanser. I play a lot of games to de-stress and have fun, but even games I really enjoy can sometimes add stress. But shapez.io does not. It is simple and yet still challenges the mind. 

  If you are at all interested in trying out the factory\automation genre I recommend giving shapez.io a try.

An abstract factory-game. You have machines which produce shapes and you have machines which produce colors. You can deploy machines to cut, to rotate and to join/staple shapes, to mix colors and to colorize shapes. All machines have different velocities and to prevent production jams you have to install multiple (cascading) Y-switches. At each level you have to produce shapes in more and more complex forms and colors and in higher numbers (so you have to design parallel production lines). There is no tutorial, but the first levels are easy and introduce the different concepts step-by-step.

This game really took me by surprise. Though heavily inspired by Factorio, the resources in Shapez.io are infinite which allows you to really focus on the task at hand - building efficient factories to construct various shapes and unlock upgrades. 

With the exception of two near-impossible-without-a-guide levels (20 and 26), the game is fun, fair and well-presented. I thought I'd stop at level 26, but then the developer gave us the Wires update which introduces a whole new layer of logic, and I'm completely absorbed in the end-game: building an automatic "Make Anything Machine".

The lack of Steam overlay, screenshots and achievements is the only real black mark on this otherwise gem of a game - it's my most played of 2020 and I highly recommend it.

I have a like/dislike relationship with this game. I like the trial and error for most of the shapes that you need to combine. I dislike that since playing it, I have had dreams about making my flows a little more efficient. 

As others have said, this game is similar to Factorio, but without the survival aspect. I did not like the survival part of that game. Other games that this is similar to are SpaceChem and Blueprint Tycoon. However, instead of having an overworld map and a building inside map like those games, everything is on the overworld in this game. So, you can see your inputs and outputs next to each other if you want. If you enjoyed those games, then you will likely enjoy this game.

If you have never played those games, and the video/images of this game on the store page look confusing, this may help. The game starts off simple. You start off by placing parts (extractors) on specific shapes on the map. Then, you add a conveyor belt to move the items that those extractors pull off the ground from the extractor to a central hub. As you add more of the requested shapes, you are rewarded with tools and tool upgrades that allow you to get more items at once, and move them faster. Eventually, you will be tasked with taking shapes apart and recombining them into new shapes. Finally, you will add various paint colors to the parts.

There is no story. There is just extracting, changing, and depositing. As you do more, you increase the speed of your system, and extract more, change faster, and deposit more. You can make things as efficient or not efficient as you want. I think this game is more enjoyable if you enjoy flows and processes with inputs and outputs (be it games, work, or whatever).

Shapez.io has no set time to complete your current shape. So, you can focus on the level up shapes while trickling in the current level's shape, or build your own shapes. You can have a single processor for a shape, or you can build multiple processors to create multiples of the same shape.

Once you hit level 20, some of the shapes get complicated. I had to look up the Level 20 "Logo" shape to figure out the small square in the bottom left. Once I learned how to do that, some of the later ones were easier, because I was able to use a similar process.

Overall, I enjoy the game. I recommend this to people who enjoy flows and processes.

If you like Satisfactory, Factorio, Automation Empire, etc, this is your next game.
You progressively have to build more complex and composited shapes, for which you unlock more capable processing nodes and higher troughput.
There is no real possibility of losing the game, since you can always rebuild anything for free by hand.
Copy&Pate or Cut&Paste costs a specific type of shape, which you start producing at one point in the game.
You will find youself more and more often unlocking a new processing node, redesigning a factory network (a collection of belts and nodes which produce a certain complex shape) in order to increase throughput, reduce footprint, ...
Then you will go over all areas on the infitie map,  where you built a previous generation of factory and swap it out for the new design.
Peaceful, relaxing. engaging... You do not need to balance things, you do not need to overproduce every step of the way, but at some point you want to.
Just for the Dopamine of having :
Mining Output > Cutting Output > Coloring Output > Stacking Output
... Oh I can split a line of my cut & colored shape here and feed it to this new area...
1 hour later ...
What was I doing before I came here?

In my first few hours of the game, I treated it like an idle game, make one producer then I would be done and wait for it to finish up. At some point, I felt that the game was so boring that I didn't want to play anymore. Then I discovered how to make a FACTORY, my whole perception of this game flipped. Instead of making one or two "it will work for now" producers of the needed shape I would make a design for the shape that could be copied and pasted over and over in a big tower using splitters and balancers to make one flow of input and output. For every shape, I could make a new blueprint for a factory and mass-produce the shape. This is easily one of the best use of $5 for my 36 hour game. 

If you feel like this game isn't for you, try the free version on the website shapez.io.

Low-key Factorio. Got a less complex, more-abstract resource/tech tree, but in an odd way that satisfied me *more* - it makes it feel more purely like solving a puzzle. The infinite map/lack of enemies/lack of resource costs also help make it a more relaxed, puzzly experience.

A short, relaxing, & "purified" variant of factorio.
Factorio is still better.

+No walking, traversal in general has been tremendously reduced, especially since you can setup fast travel points just by right clicking on the map
+Unlimited resources and buildings allow the game to have a tighter focus on logistics
+belt planner allows you to build straight belt lines without needing a steady hand
+Unlocking new buildings and features requires more complex and different shapes, including levels that require a minimal manufacturing speed instead of large quantities

+/-Weird logistic numbers force you to think differently about your setups, but also makes your setups liable to inefficiency when you get upgrades, making reconstruction a common task in the game
+/-Linear tech tree enforces various aspects of the game's challenge, but unmotivates you to beat the next level if it's for an upgrade you don't really care about (like the throughput reader)

-various simple features (like blueprinting, throughput reading, etc.) are locked behind the tech tree when they should've been unlocked from the start
-painting is incredibly lopsided and slow, asking you to make weird setups that take long enough to figure out that you'll usually beat the current level with a slow and basic setup while making an upgrade tree setup
-blueprinting (copying setups and placing them down) requires you to craft and send in cash just to do so. More annoying is that you can't simply move setups by 1 tile and have to pay for cut pasting as well at the same price as copying too. The fact that it's relatively cheap to do so makes the requirement completely pointless.
-unlocking tech makes you wait 5 seconds before you can continue playing

It's not perfect--it feels almost too simple (at least in the early stages), the copy&paste requiring shapes is aggravating (also, is it actually possible to save blueprints, or can I only use whatever I copy?), and there are a few idiosyncracies I've found when attempting to curve a belt near an unused splitter/merger output (the belt cannot be curved; it *always* takes items out of the splitter), but it's very addicting to play. I keep coming back to this game to improve throughput and change entire sections of my factory to create new shapes more efficiently.

One complaint I really have, though, is that I can't actually use copy&paste very effectively. Aside from requiring a *lot* of difficult-to-produce shapes, I can't seem to figure out how to build anything from a template, instead having to one-at-a-time adapt items I have nearby (this makes systems of sequential operations tedious to construct). Items like painters or stackers are very particular about what inputs you use, and I have to interleave my belts. This is a lot of fiddly work that I had to do many times in the early game, and they're slow, so I can't just use one or even five. Even with copy and paste, I have to wait a while for my stash of Copy Shapes to build back up, *find somewhere in my factory* that I have an existing not-too-horrible design, copy it, paste it, fix all the bugs that the new layout caused (I'd love a feature that deletes shapes off of a belt by clicking it, somewhat like Factorio's F button except without picking up the items), and then have to live with crappy throughput until I can paste it a few more times.
I have been addicted to this game for days. A real game, no ads, no bullshit, just a great strategy game with far more depth than I expected from the preview. Totally worth the money.

I initially had a lot of fun with this on the website shapez.io. If you're interested in this game, check it out there first. It's free and you can transfer your save to Steam if you want to purchase it.

shapez.io is a minimalist take on Factorio, where you aren't restricted by resources, but rather only by your imagination. There's a certain zen to its simplicity. You build factories that chop up, paint, stack, and piece together various shapes. You start with only a few options for building, but quickly unlock more as your deliver the required materials. Many are direct upgrades, allowing you to retrofit or rebuild old factories with new technologies. Eventually you unlock circuits that allow you to automate things further, creating completely independent factories.

At a certain point, Shapez's simple premise takes a turn for the worse, adding in unintuitive puzzle-like mechanics to the previously simple shapebuilding. Floating parts, empty layers, and a weird set of logic behind it all makes it more frustrating than rewarding. It doesn't help that the system for stacking shapes is bug-ridden, sometimes locking you out of progressing if you happen to have made a mistake in a stacking formula. This system is purposefully obtuse, with prominent community members claiming these puzzle-like aspects "make the game worth playing." To me, they keep it from being something I want to continue playing. 

It's cheap, so I still recommend it. If you enjoy what you played online, and you're okay with some bad design choices and bugs, it's worth the $5 pricetag.

It's a great game.  As a Factorio player, I like the simpler design of this game.  But after only about six to ten hours, you finish everything, and you really don't have any new or exciting problems to solve.  This game is really great until you reach the end.  You can keep playing and improving things, but it starts to feel repetitive and bland like a cookie clicker game.  So it's not quite as great as Factorio, but it is still very fun to play the first four or five hours of a playthrough.

This game is also a little bad on memory management.  While you can build numerous, large factories, you still have to be mindful of the tick time.  If you get too creative, you might slow down your game!  One time, I had an average tick speed of about 1.5 ms per tick (pretty fast), and then I needed to extract a shape that was quite far from the center of the map (around a thousand units along both axes).  After routing those shapes back to the center, my tick speed would still average out to around 1.5 ms per tick, but it would spike to 4 - 6 ms per tick, forcing me to lower the tick rate from 240 Hz to 120 Hz.  That was caused by only one extraction site far from the center, so that's kind of disappointing.  You still have plenty of space to build around the center, though, and in the early parts of a playthrough, everything is perfect and works just fine.  Performance is much less of a concern in Factorio than it is in this game.

Probably arising from the suboptimal memory management, this game has trouble maintaining accurate throughputs in large processing lines (having many steps in "crafting").  The numbers say that something will work at certain speeds, but if your factories are large at all, there will be enough of a performance drop that the ratios don't work out the way they should.  (Of course, I rarely see Factorio have that kind of problem.)  I shouldn't compare this game to Factorio too much because it's cheaper, and there's simply less (not a bad thing).  It's like comparing a squirt gun to a kinetic energy penetrator.

I find that this game is worth the money.  For five bucks, it provides many hours of fun, depending on how fast you intend to reach the main goal.

Revising my review since I've dumped a ton of time into the game.

The game still has annoyances that make me reluctant to recommend it, but it is fun.

The belt placement continues to be an annoyance. In later stages, scaling up can be problematic. You do eventually unlock the ability to copy/paste designs which help, but copy/pasting isn't 'free', it costs a number of a specific shapes. Certain UI features aren't intuitive.

The biggest issues for me are:

* Belt rotation is not honored. If a belt is rotated to face right and you drag from right to left, it faces left.
* There is a rotate button, but no keybind to rotate in the opposite direction. The issue is the same for selecting variants of a building/factory/whatever. You can move forward through the list, but not backwards.
* Late game requires you to scale to obscenely high levels unless you don't mind idling. This normally wouldn't be an issue, but the controls feel cumbersome for this.
* Late game has timing bugs and performance issues.

The core gameplay is fun. I will keep playing, but the issues above still stand. 

Side Note: this game is open source and the source code can be found on GitHub: https://github.com/tobspr/shapez.io

Great game that captures the automation and basebuilding of Factorio, Satisfactory, and other industrial simulation style game but without having to deal with combat. Took me roughly 20 hours on the first play through to finish level 18 and unlock Free Play Mode. The biggest challenge is coming up with new and creative ways to organize the various processes, otherwise you end up cut/paste a cutting/painting/etc module that works and using just that all over your map which takes some interest out of the game.

Wiring Update:
I've put another 30+ hours into the game since the update (and started a new factory). The tutorials for when you finally get the unlocking any of the wiring components in the late 20s are pretty bad. There is no reason to integrate the first few components you get as you don't unlock the logic elements until last before freeplay. Unless you have a background and experience in designing circuitry/programming, the tutorials will do absolutely nothing for helping you fully integrate these new components into a working factory, let alone work towards making a "Make Anything Machine". Very frustrating as I love this game but just don't even know where to start with utilizing these new components. There are also some throughput related bugs that now courtesy of the belt readers, even perfectly mathed out factories do not reliably produce a full belt's worth of shapes. This, plus the lack of guidance with the wiring, made for a frustrating experience upon reaching free play.

Sure, you've heard a lot about Factorio and Satisfactory, and you think you would like to play either game... but you're cheap, Factorio has NEVER had a sale, and $30 seems like a lot. WHAT TO DO??

Shapez.io will do. It's only a few bucks, and if even that's too much, a good portion of the game can be played completely free on their website.

Shapez has problems. There are balance issues that become apparent in the later stages. [strike]There's a game-ending bug that makes the final level broken.[/strike] The soundtrack, while catchy at first, is better turned off before its looping eats your brain. Shapez appears to be Javascript running in a self-contained browser, and that may uncover performance problems.  Scrolling across the vast map is painfully slow.

That said, the fix to some of these problems -- including the game-ending stacker bug -- is alleged to be arriving in about a week.  Unfortunately, it is coming with a whole new *layer* of functionality (wires) that should cause all new problems! The game is under active development by a single developer, so this review will be out of date within weeks.  But I think there's a warning to be made:

It feels like they have fallen into the trap that is eating Minecraft -- they are providing the bare atoms for building a world, allowing the clever-but-insane types to create **ANYTHING**.  They're bringing redstone to their world. While it is academically interesting to see what people can build, the *game* starts to suffer, I feel.

As it sits today, though, [strike]modulo the game-breaking bugs,[/strike] the game is catchy and fun and has destroyed days of my time. It is a great deal, and I recommend it, but I think you should prepare yourself to walk away when it gets insane.  

I should take that advice, too.

Edit: As promised, the 'Wires' update has made some changes to the balance, the broken stacker/cutter has been fixed, and the soundtrack extended, along with some performance fixes that I can't say I really noticed.  I haven't yet gotten to play with the new Wires system, but so far I'm pretty happy with the update.

The end game goal was to build a rocket. So what do you do after that? Build more rockets? See how many rockets per minute you can get to? Replay the game and it's still the same solutions to the same problems.

Don't get me wrong, it's still well worth the price, hence the positive review. It just frustrates me to see a games potential being squandered when it would take comparatively little effort from the devs to dramatically increase how long it holds my attention. The game map is filled with shapes and colors and you're tasked with manipulating those items to deliver a specific shape of a specific color to the Hub in the center of the map.  It's a decent amount of fun and I'd recommend at any price point under $10.  

I did suffer some frustration with the game though.  As the game goes on, you're tasked with delivering more and more objects to the Hub.  In order to do so, you have to keep up your buildings and belts and not strip them down.  The massive amount of buildings and belts I had to make caused FPS issues until the game became unplayable.  The developer has made some optimizations that allowed me to go deeper into the game.

I'm writing this review as I wait to deliver 2,200 more objects to the hub at a rate of 6 objects per second.  Since I can't build large setups to pass each level quickly, I have to resort to sitting and waiting.

Still, I'd probably recommend if you like games like Factorio or Satisfactory.

Well, the tl;dr is that for a $5 dollar game, I've gotten 40+ hours of entertainment and enjoyment. That in itself should tell you something.

But lets dig in a bit.

Shapez.io has a interesting minimalist take on the traditional factory builder style game. You get a (I assume randomly) generated field of shapes and colors, and are given a variety of increasingly complex shapes to create from the shapes/colors around you with the machines you have.

As you progress you increase the speed of your machines, unlock new types of machines, and unlock more complex or niche varieties of machines you already have. This works to have an almost integrated tutorial system, where each level gives you a new tool, and then helps ease you into the use of that tool.

However, it never really gets old. The shapes begin getting complex in ways that require new approach's to your manufacturing systems, and once you hit freeplay the goals shift from being a certain number of shapes, to a certain rate of production/delivery of the shapes, this forces players to adapt and try to either create more efficient designs, or consume large chunks of their world with expansive machines to pump out more of the shapes.

Now there are some downsides, for one, one of the major shapes in the games progression relies on a really odd and counter-intuitive mechanic to make, although once you get it figured out it is relatively simple to produce, it can make trying to naturally discover how to make that shape somewhat challenging (beyond a traditional trial/error system, due to the mechanic almost being bug-like in nature). HOWEVER, thats the only shape I've found that has an issue like that, and from browsing the discord/reddit it seems it really is only that one shape that has that issues.

Additionally, there are some optimization issues with the end-game. Until you have 12/16 of the hubs inputs filled with maxed out conveyor production of 3 or 4 layer shapes, you likely wont notice it, but once you get to making "everything machines" or ramping production of the Tier VIII+ upgrade materials, you will feel it. However, the dev has made a few optimization updates, and from what I've read the game will likely continue to get optimization updates, especially as it just received the wires update, which dropped the whole new wires/logic system mechanic.

Speaking on that. Honestly, not much to say regarding the wires mechanic, it functions like basically every other boolean based logic system in games, if you've done redstone computers in minecraft, or any wiring in terraria, it'll be a very familiar system, and offers some very interesting ideas for late game machines and automation.

All in all, if I'd paid $20 for this game I still would feel like I got a fair amount for my money. Its a solid game, easily a 8/10 or 9/10 for its genre and what its trying to be (minimalist factory builder), but given that it also is only $5, its an easy sell for me. Give it a try, I don't think you'll regret it.

Seriously, though, this game is fantastic. Shapez.io innovates on the concept that Factorio is, a 2D factory builder, by making it essentially bare-bones. It does not involve combat, depleting resource nodes, or even power (not for now, an update is coming soon), which are some of the more challenging aspects of a game like Factorio. This minimalistic approach to such a genre makes the game quite enjoyable, but not necessarily easy or simple. The challenge and thrill of designing efficient layouts of machines and belts is still very much there. And, as you progress through the linear milestones, unlocking new "buildings" or machines to work with, the game's complexity increases along with it. You're still getting all the action of a factory builder in this seemingly dumbed down game, and this is certainly a good thing. To top it all off, a $4 price tag for a game like this made by a single person is essentially a steal. I will go so far to say that this game is severely underpriced for the amount of quality work that has gone into this game. So, do yourself a favor and pick this game up now (the price will increase to $6 after the power update) and enjoy Shapez.io, a simple but amazingly well crafted factory game.

Update 10/9/20:
The wires update has finally been released (10/8 it was released I believe). This update appears to add a whole new level of complexity to the game, a second layer that contains wires that are used to control factory machines. This update also brought along several other changes, mainly to the user interface. The settings menu looks complete and clean, an animated factory background for the title screen was implemented, splash text was put on the title, and much more. These little changes make the game that much better. i have to seriously give props to the guy that is making this game, he has been hard at work for months developing this and it is absolutely fantastic. The price increased just a buck to $4.99, but it is still worth every bit of that. I wouldn't be disappointed to buy it at that price at all. This update has brought many good things, so consider picking this game up to enjoy a well made game.

A chill, minimalist, almost zen kind of factory game. Factorio was always a bit too much for me, but shapez.io is actually perfect in my need for simplistic graphics and simple but engaging gameplay. My factory is a spaghetti mess, but I suck at productivity optimization so no surprise there.

Extremely good minimalist design.  I've played every major factory builder out there, and for me, this game is perfection. The challenge is pure and simple: maximize the number of things you deliver that fit each of the templates demanded by the hub.

The constraints make perfect sense: There are only so many delivery points available into the hub.  There are only so many tools you can use to manipulate things and get them delivered.  (These unlock in a very sensible progression.)

Over time, I found myself discovering design patterns, and feeling increasingly able to build more and more complex shapes with more and more complex colour schemes.

If you love to opitmize, then your library is incomplete without a copy of shapez.io
